courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: General Psychology
courses.description: A broad-based introduction to the study of behaviour and mental processes. This course is suitable for students who might be interested in taking further courses in psychology. Topics include learning, development, psychotherapy, the brain and states of consciousness, sensation and perception, memory, social behaviour, personality, psychological disorders, coping and health, stress, and others.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students who have obtained the following grade in Psychology: IB - 5 or above (HL)/GCE-AL - C or above (AL)/Cambridge Pre-U - P2 or above (Principal course)/HKALE - C or above (AL)/AP Exam - 3 or above. 
Not for students who have taken UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, you will be expected to
I. Demonstrate a basic understanding in various areas of psychology (matches with Learning Goal I)
II. Relate and apply major psychological concepts and theories in analyzing real-life situations (matches with Learning Goal I, II, III)
III. Conceptualize, structure, and express personal views, both in written and verbal formats, on various topics of psychology
(matches with Learning Goal I, II, III, IV)
IV. Develop insights about human behavior and mental processes (matches with Learning Goal I, II, III, IV)
courses.course_syllabus:
Course content
1. Introduction

3. Sensation & Perception
4. Memory

courses.required_readings: Gazzaniga, M. S., Heatherton., T. F., & Halpern, D. F. (2010). Psychological Science. Norton.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Positive Psychology in Everyday Life
courses.description:
(UGED1554 is double-coded with PSYC1020.)
Positive psychology is the scientific study of positive influences in life, namely, positive subjective experiences, positive individual traits, and positive institutions that enhance our quality of life and avert pathologies in time of adversities. This is a knowledge-based course introducing the basic concepts of positive psychology and its application in daily life. This course aims at inspiring students’ interest and self-reflection in positive psychology, as well as the healthy mindsets and lifestyles that it espouses, while encouraging students to plan and initiate habit changes via the integration of positive psychology in their daily lives.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGED1553 and UGED1554.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:

* Understand the scientific foundation of positive psychology
* Recognize the empirically validated practices that enhance individual well-being
* Obtain knowledge about the real life applications of positive psychology in different settings, e.g., educational and business organizations
* Reflect on personal experiences using positive psychological concepts
* Plan self-improvement habit changes via integration of positive psychology in their daily lives
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Topics**

* *Module 1:** **Introduction to Positive Psychology (2 hours)**

* Understanding the science of positive psychology
* Understanding the nature of positive emotions and their lasting positive impacts in one’s life and work

​**Module 2:** **Application – Individual Level (6 hours)**

* Learning about Character Strengths and Virtues
* Introducing behavioral approaches that have lasting impacts on one’s positive emotions
+ Body Wellness
+ Gratitude and Act of Kindness
+ Mindfulness and Savoring
* Understanding the stress mechanism and the basic principles in managing one’s negative emotions

* *Module 3:** **Application – Interpersonal relationship (2 hours)**

* Creating a new mindset of successful relationship
* Learning to increase Positive Resonance
* Learning to master skills of creating alliance and handling conflicts

* *Module 4: Application – Institutional Level (1 hour)**

* Case-sharing on
+ Positive Schooling
+ Positive Workplace

* *Module 5: Feedback and Consolidation (2 hours)**

* Experience sharing by students
* Discussion on problems encountered in the application of positive psychology in daily life
* Feedback on the students’ self-improvement plans in different modules

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Psychology of Personal Growth
courses.description: This course aims at providing knowledge about adjustment and personal growth to enable students to develop more effective coping skills and social behaviours. Topics include models of personality, life cycle, self-identity, love and attraction, sexual knowledge and fulfilment, marriage and family, life style and health, stress management, social skills training, assertiveness training and theories on competent personhood.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGED2591, UGED1600/SOWK1150 or SOWK1113.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, you will be expected to

I. Demonstrate a fundamental understanding in various areas of personal growth

II. Relate and apply major psychological concepts and theories in analyzing real-life situations

III. Conceptualize and express personal views, both in written and verbal formats, on various topics of personal growth

IV. Gain insights about your personal development and life experience

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Perspectives in Human Sexuality
courses.description: This course will explore current theory and research in human sexuality from a variety of perspectives in relation to one's gender, age, sexual orientation, ethnicity and other cultural backgrounds. Students will have the opportunities to critically discuss and analyse issues related to the psychological, sociocultural, and biological aspects of human sexuality, the development of sexual attitudes, values and identity across the lifespan, sexual variations and dysfunctions, sexual coercion, and diversity of sexual behaviours and lifestyles.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
2. Not for students who have taken UGEC2913.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Be familiarized with the theories and findings about human sexuality.

2. Be aware of issues about sexuality in daily life, and apply concepts learned in class to analyze these issues.

3. Be able to conceptualize, structure, and express original ideas, both in written and during tutorial discussion, on various topics of human sexuality.

4. Be able to design, direct, and regulate own study plan for problem-based learning, from identifying the problem, setting learning objectives, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what has been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Consciousness
courses.description: This course addresses topics related to consciousness, arguably the most important yet mysterious aspect of human existence. Topics to be discussed include the variation of the level of consciousness in the waking state, sleep and dreaming, hypnosis, meditation, attention, illusions, extra-sensory perception (ESP), brain decoding and mind reading, machine consciousness, etc. Emphases will be put on the research findings from psychology and neuroscience, theoretical implications, and social applications involved.
courses.course_syllabus:
Core content:

1. Different philosophical approaches to the issue of consciousness.

2. Sleep and dreaming

3. Hypnosis and meditation

4. Drugs and Biofeedback

5. Perceptual awareness

6. Unconscious perception

7. Brain decoding and mind-brain relationships

8. Machine and animal consciousness

Selective content: lucid dream, dream interpretation, free will, time perception, simulated reality, etc.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey
2. Internal Course Review
courses.required_readings:
Course handout. Due to the extraordinarily wide scope and interdisciplinary nature of this course, there is no single specific reading we think is essential for every student. Instead we give a long list of suggested readings for each major topic covered (see in attachment). Students can choose a topic to write deeply about in their final paper. MORE IMPORTANTLY, we have set up 8 web discussions for which students have to provide their ideas for various topics (see below). To provide informative and insightful ideas and thus get good marks for these questions, students will not only have to understand the lectures, but also do extra readings. Therefore although only the course handout is put here as the required reading, students actually are expected to read a lot more than that to fulfil the requirement. It is just that we do not stipulate the exact readings they have to do.

###### ## WEB DISCUSSION TOPICS ##########

* *Web Discussion 1**

* *Topic 1 - Find a scientific paper whcih suggests that sleep is essential (or unimportant) in humans.**

Within 100 words, try your best to convince your fellow students that the study provides strong support for the importance (or the lack of importance) of sleep in humans. Attach the title, journal name, issue number, page number, and abstract of the study at the end of your post (these would not count towards the word limit). Articles in the newspaper, popular magazines, or websites will not be accepted.

* *Topic 2 - Within 150 words, make 3 suggestions (with explanations) to the following patient (a 60-year-old retired woman) with insomnia.**

Patient: “I have problem going to sleep. If I can fall asleep at 3am, that would be really early. Sometimes I can’t sleep until 5 or 6. Usually I spend 1-2 hours in bed before falling asleep, even if I wait until 3pm to get in bed. That’s very frustrating. The more I urge myself to fall asleep the harder it becomes. I tried going to bed earlier for a few days, but it didn’t help. I still couldn’t sleep until 3 or 4. So I tend to get up late, around 11-12. Still, after dinner, I often feel extremely sleepy and can’t help having a nap. I can nap almost immediately whenever I get on a bus during the day too. I have a coffee every day, usually after brunch, which is around 2-3. On Tuesdays and Thursdays I have to go to a Tai Chi class at 8 in the morning, and you can imagine how hard it is for me to get up. I’ve not tried any sleep pills, as I heard that they are addictive and would lose effect after some time. Ah – I usually go to shower at 11pm and then watch TV and read newspaper before going to bed. I tried to shower earlier for a few days but it didn’t help.”

* *Topic 3 - In less than 150 words, interpret the following dream.**

You can make use of this (http://www.dreammoods.com/dreamdictionary/) and other dream dictionaries to help you, but you are not limited to that.

“There is my brother Dave. He is leisurely jogging up a green slope. He got all the way to the top and there my friend Nelson is hugging a woman. Their faces are softened by mild, rosy light of the setting sun. Gradually they dissolved into the dense, orange air… Suddenly everything disappears and I find myself in bed. I tried to go back to the slope I dream of but I can’t. So I get up and open the door. I see a long beach. The air is brisk and the sun hasn’t come out yet. The tide is full and water is rushing into my bedroom…”

* *Web Discussion 2**

* *Topic 1 - Mind-enhancing drugs should be encouraged for students in CUHK**

In less than 100 words, give one argument for and one argument against the above notion. The clarity and strength of your argument will be the most important.

* *Topic 2 - The placebo effect - useful or dangerous?**

In less than 100 words, suggest one useful and one dangerous applications of the placebo effect.

* *Web Discussion 3**

* *Topic 1 – Hypnosis, Meditation, and Level of Consciousness**

Is a meditating person at a higher or lower level of consciousness compared with a person being hypnotized? Discuss within 100 words.

* *Topic 2 – Hypnosis or Meditation?**

Which, hypnosis or meditation, would you choose to help you study better, assuming that the university provides 24-hour hypnotists and meditation trainees for each student if necessary? Discuss your choice within 100 words.

* *Web Discussion 4 (Allow attachment of files!! <2MB)**

* *Topic 1 – Unconscious Perception Products**

Find a product or service (online or on printed media) which claims to have an effect based on subliminal/unconscious perception. An example would be a self-confidence boosting CD containing subliminal messages of encouraging words played backwards. In less than 100 words, mention the product’s name, its claimed function, and your commentary on whether the claim stands or not. Include the link of the website or a scanned image (<2MB) of the printed advertisement / package of the product. Your answer will be marked based on the novelty of the product and the quality of your commentary.

* *Topic 2 – Scientific Support for ESP**

In less than 100 words, summarize a scientific study which provides support for an ESP phenomenon, and discuss whether the evidence given is strong or weak. Include the paper topic, journal name, issue number, page number, and abstract of the study at the end of your post (these would not count towards the word limit). Articles in the newspaper, popular magazines, or websites will not be accepted.

* *Topic 3 – Unconscious Marketing**

Find an advertisement on the newspaper, magazine, TV, etc., that uses unconscious perception to promote a product. In less than 100 words discuss the way this is done, and evaluate on the effectiveness. Include the link of the website or a scanned image (<2MB) of the printed advertisement / package of the product. Your answer will be marked based on the novelty of the marketing technique and the quality of your commentary.

* *Web Discussion 5 (Allow attachement of files! <5MB)**

* *Topic 1 – Mind Tricks in Art**

Give an example of how the phenomena we discussed on Lectures 8 and 9 (Attention; Creations of the Mind) are applied to one of the following art forms or media (drawing, photography, movie, music, advertisement on print, or commercials). In less than 100 words, explain what trick(s) is/are used and how, and comment on the effectiveness. Include the link to or the file of the art work (<5MB). Your answer will be marked based on the novelty of the example (as compared with your peers), the clarity of your explanation of the tricks, and the analytic quality of your comment.

* *Web Discussion 6**

* *Topic 1 – Criterion for Consciousness**

Within 100 words, list the most important criterion you think that an animal or machine has to fulfill in order to qualify as a conscious entity, and explain your answer. There is no model answer to this question, and depending on the purpose in answering this question the same person may come up with different criteria. Therefore it is good enough to clearly state your criterion and explain why it is chosen among other possible criteria.

* *Web Discussion 7**

* *Topic 1 – Libet’s Experiment and Free Will**

If, based on the results of Libet’s ERP experiment discussed in class, someone concludes that humans have no free will, would you agree? If not, what is your position? Within 100 words, state your position and provide a strong reason to justify your position. Whether the reason is clear and convincing is the key. It is fine whether you think of the reason yourself or use a reason from the literature, but in the latter case you have to provide the reference.

* *Topic 2 – How Much “Human” Is Human Enough?**

Suppose you undergo a surgery such that 30% of your brain cells are replaced by computer chips. Do you think you are still as “humanly conscious” as you are before? Discuss within 100 words.

* *Web Discussion 8**

* *Topic 1 – What Have You Got and What Should Be Added?**

In less than 100 words, (a) describe one idea/topic/question you got from this course that is the most valuable; and (b) describe one idea/topic/question you have that has not been covered in this course. If you do not have an answer for (a) you can describe two ideas for (b). The goal of this exercise is for you to reflect on what you learned from this course. Full marks will be granted (by default) for this discussion unless your description is not clear or the idea/topic/question you describe as not covered has actually been covered in class.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Your Journey into Psychology
courses.description: This course offers an orientation to help beginning students of psychology to appreciate the impact of studying psychology. Students and the teacher will explore and reflect on issues including how psychology relates to oneself, how psychologists think, and how psychology contributes to the society.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken PSYC1090.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Reflecting on how the study of psychology relates to personal life and world issues
2. Appreciating the perspectives and tools of a psychologist
3. Exploring the various paths followed by students of psychology.
courses.course_syllabus:
The uniqueness of psychology compared with other disciplines
The importance of theory and evidence for psychologists
Relationship between psychology and personal issues
Awareness, empathy, group pressure, and the study of others and yourself
Career in professional and non-professional psychology areas.
Foreseeing oneself in 5 years; alternative paths of development
The role of psychology in promoting human welfare.
courses.required_readings: Resources will be assigned by the corresponding speakers when appropriate.
courses.recommended_readings: Resources will be assigned by the corresponding speakers when appropriate.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: How Psychologists See Culture
courses.description: For humans, culture is like water for fish. We could not gain a good understanding of human behaviors without understanding culture. Taking this perspective, this course explores the ways in which culture shapes mind. The course incorporates a variety of perspectives to analyze the relationship between culture and mind—to gain insight into our own culture, human culture will be compared with animal culture and Chinese culture with non-Chinese cultures. These issues are examined in analyzing a range of psychological phenomena, from the ways in which we understand the world, understand ourselves, and relate to others around us.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken PSYC3610.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Learn how culture is studied in psychology and how psychological approach differs from other approaches.

2. Learn the role of culture in shaping mental process.

3. Learn how Chinese culture differs from other cultures.

4. Recognize issues of cultural diversity for inter-cultural contacts.
courses.course_syllabus:
Lecture 1: Introduction

Lecture 2: What is Culture?

Lecture 3: Cultural Change

Lecture 4: Acculturation

Lecture 5: Development

Lecture 6: Self and Personality

Lecture 7: Motivation

Lecture 8: Control and Choice

Lecture 9: Cognition

Lecture 10: Language and communication

Lecture 11: Emotions

Lecture 12: Attraction, close relationship, groups
courses.required_readings: Articles and book chapters related to the various topics of the course

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Communication for Healthy Relationship
courses.description: The course deals with both conceptual and practical issues in interpersonal communication. Both verbal and non-verbal communication modes will be discussed in two major domains: interpersonal relationships, including friendships, romantic relationships, and family communication patterns; as well as in the workplace, focusing on effective negotiation, management, and presentation skills. In each of these domains, students will be exposed to research on how communication modes vary as a function of factors such as gender, culture, and social status, as well as learning how to examine their own and others' communication styles.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the knowledge base of interpersonal communication theories.

2. Understand and apply psychological principles to personal, social, and organizational communication.

3. Develop effective communication skills in a variety of formats and settings.

4. Develop insight into one’s own and others’ behavior and mental processes and apply effective strategies for self-management and self-improvement.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction

3. The Self, Perception, and Interpersonal Communication:

5. Verbal Communication

6. Nonverbal Communication

7. Listening

8. Effective Communication and Emotional Sharing

9. Gender and Interpersonal Communication

10. Close Relationships and Interpersonal Communication

11. Communicating with Family

12. Communication in the Workplace

13. Technological advancement and Interpersonal Communication

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Introduction to Statistics
courses.description: Introduction to statistics as a method in describing and making inferences about numerical data. Emphasis on applications in daily life and psychological research.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken COMM3110, DSME2011, ECON2121, GRMD2102, LING3403, PHPC2015, SEEM2430, SOCI2004, SPED2600, STAT2101, 2102, 2001 or 2006.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will know the procedure to carry out statistical methods in psychology and be able to both use them in practical question and understand them in the scientific literature.
2. Students will understand the logic behind those procedures and know how to solve similar questions.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Basic concepts in statistics
2. Descriptive statistics
3. Normal Distribution
4. Hypothesis Testing I
5. Hypothesis Testing II
6. Effect size, Power
7. One-sample, Paired t-test
8. Two-sample t-test
9. One-way ANOVA
10. Correlation
11. Simple Regression
12. Chi-square test
13. Review Session
courses.required_readings: Aron, A., Aron, E. N., & Coups, E. J. (2008). Statistics for Psychology (5th ed.). Upper Saddle River, NJ: Pearson Education.
courses.recommended_readings: Green, S. B., & Salkind, N. J. (2008). Using SPSS for Windows and Macintosh: Analyzing and Understanding Data. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Pearson Education.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Experimental Design
courses.description: Introduction to the various strategies and techniques of experimental research and data analysis employed in psychology. Participation in laboratories or independent research required.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will know the basic types of experimental designs (e.g., within-subjects designs vs. between-subjects designs) and know how to use them appropriately in various situations.

2. Students will know how to address the important issues in designing and conducting psychological experiments (e.g., research ethics, literature review, control groups, presentations).
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Scientific thinking in Psychology

2. Developing research ideas

3. Experimental approaches

4. Control problem 1

5 Control problem 2

6. Experimental design 1

7. Experimental design 2

8. Other research methods

9. Measurements and data analysis

10. Scientific practice
courses.required_readings: Research In Psychology: Methods and Design (6/E) by C. James Goodwin

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Psychological Testing
courses.description: Basic principles of psychological measurement. Scaling models based on psychophysical and psychological methods, including constant methods, pair-comparisons, rank order, interval and ratio judgements. Issues in internal structure of measures such as variance and covariance, measurement error, and validity and reliability.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC2010 or any of its equivalent courses (COMM3110, DSME2010 & 2020, ECON2121, GRMD2102, SEEM2430, SOCI1004, SPED2600, STAT2101 & 2102, or STAT2001 & 2006).
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of this course, you will have a better understanding about the basic concepts and principles of psychological testing. In particular, you will know how to evaluate the quality of a psychological test scientifically.
courses.course_syllabus:
Basic Concepts in Psychological Measurement

Scales, Transformations, and Norms

Scale Construction

Test Development

Online Resources for Questionnaire Construction

Theory of Summated Scores

Reliability

Validity

Factor Analysis

Item Analysis
courses.required_readings: Cohen, R.J., & Swerdlik, M.E. (2010). Psychological Testing and Assessment: An Introduction to Test and Measurement (7th ed). New York, NY: McGraw Hill.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Qualitative Research Methods
courses.description: This course introduces students to the methods of doing qualitative research in psychology. We will begin by discussing qualitative research as a general research strategy and work through several interrelated methods of collecting qualitative data: unstructured observations, structured observations, interviews (again, varying in range from completely open-ended to more directed), diaries, and public expressions. In addition, we will discuss how to design are search project that involves qualitative methods, as well as several methods for collecting, analysing, interpreting, and writing up reports based on qualitative data. Students will be given hands-on exercises in collecting interview and observational data and will be expected to transcribe audio and/or video-recordings that they make and take field notes of their experiences.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. understand, relate and apply the key qualitative research concepts in daily circumstances

2. familiarize with the key classical and contemporary qualitative research methods in psychology

3. conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during tutorial discussions, on research methods related topics

4. design, direct and regulate group project for problem-based learning, from collecting observation data, interviewing, coding, report writing and presentation, reflecting on what have been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems
courses.course_syllabus:
What is qualitative research? How is it different from quantitative research?

Naturalistic Observation (Unstructured)

Naturalistic Observation (Structured)

How to analyze observation data

Interviewing – different methods

Interviewing – conducting structured interviews

How to analyze data obtained from interviews

Special Cases: Coding visual, sound data
courses.required_readings: Willig, C. Introducing qualitative research in psychology: adventures in theory and method. Buckingham: Open University Press.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Physiological Psychology
courses.description: The biological bases of behaviour, including central nervous system, peripheral nervous system, and the internal chemical environment. The relationship between such psychological processes as motivation, states of consciousness, memory, emotions,and learning and underlying physiological and neurophysiological events.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to achieve:

1. Understand major concepts and research findings in each major aspects of physiological psychology, and integrate knowledge for the human nervous system to form an overall impression of how it functions as unified system.

2. Be able to comprehend and assess recent research progress in selected research areas in brain sciences.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction

2. Neuron and synapse

3. Neural anatomy

4. Research methods

5. Vision

6. Other senses

7. Movement

8. Sleep

9. Emotion

10. Learning and memory

11. Language

12. Disorders
courses.required_readings: Neil R. Carlson. Physiology of behavior Allyn & Bacon.
courses.recommended_readings: Laura A. Freberg. Discovering Biological Psychology, Houghton Mifflin Company

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Sensation and Perception
courses.description: This course covers fundamental concepts and principles of sensory and perceptual processes, with an emphasis on psychophysical and scaling methods and experimental techniques. Contents include: psychophysics and scaling, sensory systems, perceptual development, constancies and illusions, and attention.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: (PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581) and PSYC2010 or its equivalent courses (COMM3110, DSME2010 & 2020, ECON2121, GRMD2102, SEEM2430, SOCI1004, SPED2600, STAT2101 & 2102 or STAT2001 & 2006).
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understanding the processes of creating perception from sensory stimuli, focusing on an approach of information processing.

2. Understanding perception from a few aspects, what is its functional goal, How is it implemented, what are the important sub-systems and how do they behave.
courses.course_syllabus:
1 Introduction

2 Physiology of Vision

3 Spatial Vision

4 Object and Structure

5 Attention

6 Color

7 Depth

8 Motion

9 High-level vision

10 Perception of other groups

11 Perception of other modalities

12 Current directions in visual perception

13 Review session
courses.required_readings: Goldstein, E. B.. Sensation and Perception. Pacific Grove, CA: Wadsworth.
courses.recommended_readings: Rock, I. Perception. Scientific American Library/W. H. Freeman.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Basic Learning Processes
courses.description: Methods and findings in the study of learning with emphasis on their relation to theories of learning. Special consideration given to the way in which learning theory may be applied to human behaviour. Some laboratory participation required.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
The above three learning goals focusing on understanding, critical thinking, and application translate specifically to the following concrete learning outcomes:
1. Students are able to explain to others what learning, memory, and behaviorism are.
2. Students are able to discuss some basic principles governing learning and memory behavior in an informative fashion.
3. Students are able to develop sensible arguments that are based upon these principles and apply them effectively to daily life observations.
4. Students can apply these principles to some other areas of psychology and even other branches of social science.
5. Students can analyze and discuss educational issues in an informative fashion.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. instinctive behaviour and simple learning
2. classical conditioning I
3. classical conditioning II
4. instrumental conditioning I
5. instrumental conditioning II
6. theories I
7. theories II
8. theories III
9. control of behaviour I
10. control of behaviour II
11. control of behaviour III
12. verbal learning I
13. verbal learning II
courses.required_readings: Domjan, M. The Principles of Learning and Behavior. CA: Wadsworth.
courses.recommended_readings: Chapters 12 and 13 from Klein, S. B.. Learning: Principles and Applications. NY: McGraw-Hill.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Memory and Cognition
courses.description: This course introduces basic concepts, theories, methods, findings, and new developments in the cognitive study of human memory. Topics to be covered include sensory memory, attention, pattern recognition, memory and forgetting, picture memory, and mental imagery.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
2. Not for students who have taken UGEB2721 or LING2201.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, you should be able to:

1) Understand the major concepts, findings, and theories in cognitive psychology

2) Be able to understand and compare cognitive theories on different topics

3) Obtain skills and experience in conducting research in cognitive psychology

4) Develop critical thinking skills to evaluate empirical evidence

5) Practice on effective communication through written and oral presentation

6) Apply the knowledge about cognition to enhance performance in daily life

7) Appreciate the values of cognitive psychology
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction

2. Approaches to the cognitive study of human mind

3. Mental chronometry

4. Perceptual processes

5. Attention

6. Memory and forgetting

7. Memory and processing of nonverbal information

8. Mental imagery

9. Levels of processing

10. Explicit and implicit memory Memory

11. Higher mental processes
courses.required_readings: Galotti, K.M.. Cognitive psychology in and out of the laboratory. Singapore: Thomson Learning Asia.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Developmental Psychology
courses.description: The goal of this course is to introduce students to the field of developmental psychology. We will explore theories, research methods, and research findings concerning physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development from infancy to old age. We will pay particular attention to the role of culture in shaping lifespan development.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite:PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
Not for students who have taken PSYC2530 or PSYC3540 or SOWK2110 or EDUC2310.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Obtain a knowledge base of developmental psychology

2. Apply major concepts, theories, and research findings in developmental psychology to analyze real-life issues

3. Understand typical research methods in developmental psychology and practice using them
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Recurrent themes and representative theories in developmental psychology

2. Typical research methods in developmental psychology

3. Classical work on cognitive development and contemporary trends

4. Classical work on moral development and contemporary trends

5. Temperament and attachment

6. Self-development and gender development

7. Achievement motivation

8. Contexts for development I: The family

9. Contexts for development II: Peers, school, neighborhood, and the media

10. Adolescence and emerging adulthood

11. Love and work during adulthood

12. Health and wellness during adulthood, aging

13. Dying, death, and grieving

1. Course Evaluation Questionnaire

2. Students’ reflection on the course

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Social Psychology
courses.description: Major concepts and methods used in studying the individual's behaviour in social settings. Interpersonal attraction, leadership, aggression, group processes, attitude change and person perception.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerepuisite: PSYC1000 or PSYC1620 or PSYC1630 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Understand concepts and theories in social psychology.

Understand how research in social psychology is conducted.

Apply social psychology to everyday life.

Effectively communicate issues relevant to social psychology.

Develop insight into your own and others’ social behaviors.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction

Groups

Attraction

Relationships

Social Self

Social Influence

Persuasion

Attitudes, Behavior, and Rationalization

Understanding Others

Social Judgment

Stereotyping, Prejudice, Discrimination

Helping, Hurting, and Cooperating

Emotion
courses.required_readings: Gilovich, T., Keltner, D. & Nisbett, R.E. Social Psychology. New York:W.W. Norton

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Personality Psychology
courses.description: This course presents the major theoretical approaches to personality and the basic techniques utilized to assess personality differences. The focus is on everyday life applications, empirical evidence in support and against the theories, and the design, application, and interpretation of personality questionnaires.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1: familiarize with the key classical and contemporary experimental studies and findings in personality psychology

2: understand, relate and apply the key personality psychological concepts to daily life

3: conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during tutorial discussions, on personality psychology related topics

4: design, direct and regulate own study plan on personality psychology, from identifying the problem, setting learning objectives, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what has been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems
courses.course_syllabus:
Course Syllabus 1. What is personality?

2. How do we go about studying personality?

3. How do we describe personality? Types, traits & interactionism

4. Biological Processes I

5. Biological Processes II

6. Psychodynamic perspective I

7. Psychodynamic perspective II

8. Neoanalytic perspective

9. Learning perspective

10. Phenomenological perspective I

11. Phenomenological perspective II

12. Cognitive self-regulation perspective I

13. Cognitive self-regulation perspective II
courses.required_readings: Carver, C. S. & Scheier, M. F. Perspectives on Personality (6th edition) Boston: Allyn & Bacon.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Neuropsychology
courses.description: This course provides basic introduction of human brain functions and the abnormal cognitive functions associated with brain damage. It focuses on exploring the relationship between the human brain and behaviours. It also examines the neural bases and clinical presentation of various types of cognitive disorders, such as dyslexia, amnesia, disorders of attention and emotion processing.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to:

1. Acquire fundamental understanding of some basic but important concepts and theories in neuropsychology.

2. Learn about the value and application of neuropsychological concepts.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week/Topic and Aims (in bullets point)

1. Introduction: Philosophy Behind Neuropsychology

• to allow students to have general idea about neuropsychology and relationships between brain and behavior

• to introduce the value of neuropsychology in understanding human behavior

2. Basic Neuroanatomy

• to introduce basic but important knowledge in major concepts about neuroanatomy, e.g., various brain regions and their associated functions, mechanism of neuronal activity

3. Methods in Neuropsychology & Hemispheric Specialization

• to introduce various methods in studying the brain functions, e.g., brain imaging techniques and study of brain-damaged patients

• to introduce the fundamental concept of hemispheric specialization and its significance in understanding our brain functions

4. Dementia

• to introduce the definition of dementia and its various subtypes and etiologies

• to briefly introduce the cognitive deficits associated with different types of dementia

5. Memory

• to introduce various memory models in understanding memory

• to briefly introduce possible etiologies and characteristics of various types of memory disorders

6. Language

• to introduce the fundamental concept of language

• to briefly illustrate the characteristics of various types of language impairment

7. Mid-Term Examination

• to be tested on the basic knowledge in neuropsychology and neuroanatomy and important concepts of brain functions, including memory and language, and the associated deficits

8. Executive Function

• to define executive functions and the associated cognitive abilities

• to briefly illustrate the characteristics of various types of executive dysfunctions

9. Object Recognition & Spatial Processing

• to briefly introduce the concept of object recognition and spatial processing

• to briefly illustrate the characteristics of various forms of impairment in object recognition and spatial processing

10. Motor Control

• to introduce the fundamental concept of motor control

• to briefly illustrate the characteristics of various types of motor control problems

11. Emotion

• to introduce the fundamental concept of emotion processing

• to briefly illustrate the characteristics of various types of emotion disorders and its relation to the brain

12. Traumatic Brain Injury

• to define traumatic brain injury

• to briefly introduce possible cognitive deficits associated with traumatic brain injury

13. Learning and Neuropsychiatric Disorders of Childhood

• to briefly introduce various types of learning and neuropsychiatric disorders of childhood
courses.required_readings: Martin, G. N. (2006). Human Neuropsychology (2nd Ed). Hertfordshire, UK: Prentice Hall Europe.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Human Intelligence
courses.description: This course introduces major theories, issues, methods, findings, and new developments in human intelligence from the perspective of cognitive psychology. Topics to be covered include representations and structures of knowledge, complex cognitive skills (e.g., language and thought, discourse comprehension, and problem-solving) and related mental operations, as well as cross-cultural studies of cognition.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
2. Not for students who have taken UGEB2721.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Grasp the general knowledge in cognitive psychology

2) Identify a research question in cognitive psychology, design and conduct experiments, analyze data, and report empirical findings

3) Weigh different research findings on a target issue based on specific theories (such as the direct access hypothesis and the phonological mediation hypothesis in visual word recognition)

4) Enhance perception and performance in real life situations using the knowledge learned in the course, such as applying the findings from language comprehension studies to improve reading efficiency

1. Introduction

2. Knowledge representation

3. Categorization

4. Semantic networks

5. Language and thought I & II

6. Language processing I

7. Language processing II

8. Discourse comprehension

9. Cross-language research

10. Problem solving

11. Cognitive analysis of human intelligence

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Psychology and Law
courses.description: This course provides a general introduction to the interdisciplinary field of psychology and law. Topics covered include criminality, criminal profiling, mental competence, malingering, eyewitness testimony, lie detection, jury decision-making and risk and needs assessment in correctional psychology. Implications of research findings will be discussed to evaluate the practicality of the constructs, and emphasis will be given to the relevance of psychological concepts to the different legal systems around the world.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Be familiarized with the key classical theories and contemporary findings in forensic and criminal psychology.

2. Be aware of issues about psychology and law in daily life, and apply concepts learned in class to analyze these issues.

3. Be able to conceptualize, structure, and express original ideas, both in written and during tutorial discussion, on various topics of psychology and law.

4. Be able to design, direct, and regulate own study plan for problem-based learning, from identifying the problem, setting learning objectives, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what has been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction

2. Crime and the Public

3. Theories of crime

4. Mental disorders and crime, competence and insanity

5. Psychology of police: suspect interview and police interrogation

6. Criminal profiling: methods and validity

7. Violent and sexual offenders; Victimology

8. Eyewitness testimony

9. Lie detection

10. Correctional psychology: Risk and needs assessment

11. Correctional psychology: Psychological therapies for offenders

12. Trial process, jury selection and jury decision making

13. Conclusions
courses.required_readings: Howitt, D. (2018). Introduction to forensic and criminal psychology (6th ed.). Harlow, England: Pearson.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Psychology of Language
courses.description: This course brings together the theoretical and empirical tools of psychology and linguistics to study the mental processes underlying the acquisition and use of language, with special emphasis on the topics of grammar and psychology, psycholinguistic investigations of grammar, language development in the child, problems of meaning, and language and cognition.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
1. Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
2. Not for students who have taken ENGE3610 or LING3202.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students are able to explain to others what language, language learning,

bilingualism, syntax, semantics, phonology, and speech are

2. Students are able to discuss some basic principles governing language learning and processing in an informative fashion

3. Students are able to develop sensible arguments that are based upon these principles and apply them effectively to daily life observations

4. Students can analyze and discuss issues surrounding language education in an informative fashion
courses.course_syllabus:
1. General Introduction

2. Origins of Language

3. Language and Thought

4. Speech Perception

5. Speech Production

6. Sentence Processing

7. Language Acquisition

8. Bilingualism
courses.required_readings: Carroll, D. W. (2008). Psychology of language (5th Ed.). CA: Wadsworth.
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Origins

Donald, M. (1999). Preconditions for the evolution of protolanguages. In M. C. Corballis & S. E. G. Lea (Eds.), The descent of mind (pp. 138-154). New York: Oxford University Press.

Chang, L. (2007). 语言进化，《进化心理学》(pp.329-365) 广东高等教育出版社

2. Language and Thought

understanding of false beliefs. In P. Mitchell & K. Riggs (Eds.), Children’s

reasoning and the mind (pp. 191-228). Hove, East Sussex: Psychology Press.

Hollebrandse, B. (1998). On theory of mind and sequence of tense in Dutch. In B. Hollebrandse (Ed.), New Perspectives on Language Acquisition (pp. 147-153). University of Massachusetts occasional papers in linguistics, GSLA, Amherst, MA.

3. Acquisition

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Psychology of Music
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to discuss and explore the psychological mechanisms involved in the perception, development, performance, and interpretation of music. These topics are approached via neurological, cognitive, developmental, and socio-cultural methods. Some of the topics include the perception of pitch and rhythm, musical structure, practice and the development of musical expertise, and the social dynamics in an ensemble. It is hoped that after taking this course students are able to analyze and discuss a range of musical phenomena and activities from a psychological point of view.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) An understanding of the primary issues discussed in the contemporary study of psychology of music

(2) An understanding of the methods commonly used in the study of psychology of music

(3) An ability to discuss musical phenomena and activities from a psychological point of view

(4) Application of knowledge in psychology of music to music education, practice, and performance
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) General introduction: The scope of psychology of music

(2) Music as acoustic signals: Sound wave, pitch, timbre, and hearing

(3) Music and the brain

(4) Perception of pitch and rhythm

(5) Musical structure: The Generative Theory

(6) Development: How music is learned

(7) Practice

(8) Performance

(9) The social psychology of music

(10) Music and emotion

(11) Meaning in music

(12) The origins of music 1

(13) The origins of music 2
courses.required_readings: Tan, S.-L., Pfordresher, P., & Harre, R. (2010). Psychology of Music: From Sound to Significance. Psychology Press: Hove and New York.
courses.recommended_readings:
Mithen, S. (2006). The Singing Neanderthals: The Origins of Music, Language, Mind, and Body. Harvard University Press: Cambridge, MA.

Thompson, W. F. (2009). Music, Thought, and Feeling: Understanding the Psychology of Music. Oxford University Press: Oxford New York.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Problem Solving and Creativity
courses.description: This course is to introduce cognitive and social approaches to problem-solving and creativity. This includes ways in which creativity, intelligence, E.Q., and interpersonal sensitivity affect the kinds of problems to be solved and the manner in which they are solved. Social and cultural contexts of problem solving and creativity will be explored. The role of problem solving and creativity for turning ideas into action (entrepreneurship) will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. understand, relate and apply the key concepts of problem solving to daily life

2. familiarize with the key classical and contemporary experimental studies and findings in problem solving

3. conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during tutorial discussions, on topics related to problem solving

4. design, direct and regulate own study plan for problem-based learning, from identifying the problem, setting learning objectives, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what has been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: What is the psychology of thinking?

2. Methodology: Tracing the thinking processes, Descriptive, prescriptive, and normative models

3. Problem solving: Problem representation, Problem solving strategies

4. Reasoning: Inductive vs. deductive reasoning Guessing

5. Judgment: Probability and Bayes’s theorem, Explanation-based judgment

6. Decision making: Expected utility theory, Prospect theory

7. Creativity: Types of creativity, Functional fixedness and mental set

8. Individual differences: Experts vs. novices, Development and learning

9. Thinking in the social context: Social dilemmas, Emotion, fairness, and justice

10. Unconscious thinking: Intuition, Unconscious thought theory

11. The rationality debate: Are we rational? Bounded rationality and ecological rationality

12. Conclusion: Human thinking vs. animal thinking
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course Evaluation Questionnaire

2. Students’ reflection on the course
courses.required_readings:
Textbook:

1. Baron, J. (2008). Thinking and Deciding (4th Ed.). NY: Cambridge University Press.

2. Galotti, K.M. (2007/08). Cognitive psychology in and out of the laboratory (4th ed. -- international student edition). Singapore: Thomson Learning Asia.

3. Hastie, R., & Dawes, R. M. (2010). Rational Choice in an Uncertain World: The Psychology of Judgment and Decision Making (2nd Ed.). LA: SAGE Publications, Inc.

4. Robertson, S. I. (1999). Types of thinking. London: Routledge.

5. Robertson, S. I. (2001). Problem Solving. PA: Psychology Press.

Articles:

A. Dijksterhuis, A., Bos, M.W., Nordgren, L.F., & van Baaren, R.B. (2006). On making the right choice: The deliberation-without-attention effect. Science, 311, 1005-1007.

B. Kahneman, D. (2002). Maps of bounded rationality: A perspective on intuitive judgment and choice. In T. Frängsmyr (Ed.), Les Prix Nobel: The Nobel Prizes 2002 (pp. 449–489). Stockholm: Nobel Foundation.

C. Marewski, J. N., Gaissmaier, W., & Gigerenzer, G. (2010). Good judgments do not require complex cognition. Cognitive Processing, 11, 103–121.

D. Drunco, M. A. (2004). Creativity. Annual Review of Psychology, 55, 657–687.

E. Shafir, E., & LeBoeuf, R. (2002). Rationality. Annual Review of Psychology, 53, 491–517.

Other relevant journal articles will be provided in lectures.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Machine Learning in Psychology
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with a foundational understanding of machine learning concepts and techniques, and their applications in psychology. Throughout the course, students will gain hands-on experience with various algorithms, such as supervised and unsupervised learning, techniques for feature selection, model evaluation, and the use of advanced methods such as neural networks and large language models. The course is designed to enable students to apply machine learning tools to psychological research, thereby fostering skills in data-driven hypothesis testing and research innovation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, you will be able to:

1. understand machine learning concepts, including different learning paradigms, algorithms, and the theoretical foundations underlying these methods.
2. develop and implement machine learning models, utilizing various techniques to analyze and interpret psychological data.
3. integrate machine learning methodologies with empirical psychological research to enhance data analysis, hypothesis testing, and the generation of new research questions.
4. communicate the rationale, process, and results of machine learning analyses in psychology to a diverse range of audiences.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Overview of machine learning and its applications in psychology
* Types of machine learning, basic terminology, and algorithmic thinking
* Data preprocessing and feature selections
* Supervised learning techniques
* Model evaluation, comparison, and selection
* Unsupervised learning techniques
* Basics of Neural networks and deep learning
* Advanced techniques in machine learning
* Communication for results of machine learning
* Current trends and future directions of machine learning
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course Evaluation Questionnaire
2. Students’ reflection on the course
courses.required_readings: Müller, A. C., & Guido, S. (2016). *Introduction to machine learning with Python: A guide for data scientists*. Sebastopol, CA: O'Reilly Media, Inc.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Computational Modeling in Psychology
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the principles and practices of computational modeling. Students will learn to use computational models to understand cognitive functions (e.g., memory, language, cognitive control) arise from computations in the brain and study social interactions and group behaviors. Topics will include the purpose of models, distinguishing good modeling from bad, implementing a model, fitting a model to data, evaluating the fit of a model, comparing competing models, investigating special cases of a model, and developing and testing new models. Additionally, the course will introduce students to the latest modeling approaches that have been employed to understand human behaviors, including neural networks and large language models.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, you will be able to:

1. Comprehend the basic principles of computational modeling and its roles in psychological research.
2. Develop basic computational models to simulate psychological phenomena and evaluate its performance.
3. Integrate computational models with empirical data from psychological experiments.
4. Communicate the concepts and results of computational models to a non-specialist audience.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Key principles and concepts in computational modeling
* Purposes and steps in developing computational models
* Fitting models with empirical data
* Model evaluation, comparison, and selection
* Use of computational models in cognitive processes: brain functions
* Use of computational models in cognitive processes: memory
* Modeling social interactions and group behaviors
* Use of large language models in psychology
* Applications of computational models to understand real-life problems
* Communication for results of computational modeling
* Current trends and future directions of computational modeling
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course Evaluation Questionnaire
2. Students’ reflection on the course
courses.required_readings:
Marr, D. (2010). Vision: A computational investigation into the human representation and processing of visual information. London, England: The MIT Press.

Farrell, S., & Lewandowsky, S. (2018). Computational modeling of cognition and behavior. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press.
courses.recommended_readings:
Anderson, J.R. (1996). The architecture of cognition (1st ed.). Cambridge: Psychology Press.

Minsky, M. (1988). Society of mind. New York: Simon and Schuster, Inc.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Educational Psychology
courses.description: This course introduces the application of theoretical principles and research findings from the field of psychology to educational settings. Topics to be covered include general instructional issues, learning and motivation, effective instruction, educating students with special needs, measurement and evaluation. Special emphasis is placed on the understanding and solution of educational problems in the local community.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
Not for students who have taken EDUC3311.
courses.learning_outcomes:
I. Demonstrate a fundamental understanding in various concepts and theories of educational psychology
II. Be able to discuss and explain some principles governing learning from a psychological perspective
III. Be able to critically examine educational research and their implications
IV. Be able to analyse and discuss educational issues in an informative fashion
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Human Development
2. Individual Differences
3. Cognitive Learning Theories
4. Behavioral Learning Theories
5. Constructive Learning
6. Grouping
7. Instruction and Planning
8. Motivation
9. Managing the Classroom
10. Assessment
courses.required_readings: Slavin, R. E. (2009). Educational psychology: Theory and practice (9th Ed.). Merrill.
courses.recommended_readings:
(1) Corno, L. (2000). Looking at homework differently. The Elementary School Journal, 100, 529-548.
(2) Schraw, G., Flowerday, T., & Lehman, S. (2001). Increasing situational interest in the classroom. Educational Psychology Review, 13, 211-224.
(3) Trautwein, U., Ludtke, O., Marsh, H. W., Koller, O., & Baumert, J. (2006). Tracking, self-concept and interest in ninth-grade mathematics. Journal of Educational Psychology, 98, 788-806.
(4) Pressley, M., Gaskins, I. W., Solic, K., Colins, S. (2006). A portrait of benchmark school: How a school produces high achievement in students who previously failed. Journal of Educational Psychology, 98, 282-306.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Culture and Psychology
courses.description: People born in different cultures experience different physical and social environments. These factors combine with unique historical heritages to shape mind. This course exposes students to accumulated knowledge on the interactive relationships between culture and mind. Special attention will be given to China and Asia-Pacific.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581.
Not for students who have taken PSYC1620.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Learn theories and concepts of cross-cultural psychology.

- Develop a comprehensive understanding of how culture influences mental processes.

- Critically examine Chinese culture: its distinctive features and similarities with other cultures.

- Become aware of psychological issues surrounding cross-cultural exchanges, diversity, and globalization.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction. How are individuals similar to and different from others? Who are Chinese? What is Chinese culture?

2. What Is Culture? How does culture get in our head? Do animals have cultures? What is cultural learning?

3. Cultural Change. How do cultures emerge and change? What are the processes of cultural change? Are cultures converging?

4. Acculturation. What happens when people move to a new culture? What happens when people have more than one culture?

5. Development. What is the sensitive period of culture? Differences in childhood experience across cultures.

6. Self and Personality. Culture and personality. Independent self vs. interdependent self.

7. Motivation. “Standing out” versus “fitting in.” Culture and self-evaluation.

8. Control and Choice. Influencing others and adjusting to the environment. Paradox of choice.

9. Thinking. Cultural differences in habits of thoughts: differences in attention, perception, attribution, and reasoning.

10. Language and Communication. Language and thought. High and low context culture. Sapir-Whorf hypothesis.

11. Emotions. Does emotion expression vary across cultures? Cultural variation in ideal affect. Happiness.

12. Groups and Social Relationships. Base of interpersonal attraction. Friendship. Inter-group relationships.

13. Mental and Physical health. Culture bound syndromes. Culture and physical health.
courses.required_readings: Heine, S. J. (2008). Cultural psychology. New York: Norton.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Culture, Groups and Social Behaviour
courses.description: This is an introductory course on social dilemmas. Social dilemma is a mixed-motive situation in which a person’s selfish interest to maximize his or her own gain may undermine the collective interest of everyone. The basic research question is “why do people cooperate?” Social dilemma is a theoretical model describing the general conflict between cooperation and competition in all sorts of real-life situations, e.g., conserving energy, donating blood, contributing to charities, or using public transportation. The course introduces different types of social dilemmas like prisoner’s dilemma, public goods, and resource dilemmas. Emphasizing a social psychological perspective, we will also cover psychological factors like leadership, trust, criticality, and social value orientation that have been found to affect cooperation in social dilemmas. Theories and concepts will be illustrated through various social dilemma games in tutorials.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC2620.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Apply social psychology theories and methods to analyze cooperation in real life.

2. Learn how to evaluate psychological concepts criticality and skeptically through different research methods.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction

2. Fundamental concepts

3. Prisoner’s dilemma

4. Public goods

5. Resource dilemma

6. Intergroup dilemmas

7. Social value orientation and altruism

8. To be or not to be nice
courses.required_readings: Komortia, S. S., & Parks, C. D. (1996). Social dilemmas. Madison, WI: Brown & Benchmark.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Psychology of Gender
courses.description: Gender affects people’s experiences, judgments and beliefs. This course reviews various perspectives on the psychology of gender. An analytical approach to understanding socialization, policies and cultures from a gendered perspective will be explored. Consequences of gender bias will be discussed. Upon completion of the course, students should demonstrate basic understanding of the major conceptual models of gender psychology and have better awareness of gender issues in different social and cultural contexts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
I. Demonstrate a fundamental understanding in various concepts and theories of the psychology of gender

II. Be able to critically examine gender research and their implications

III. Be able to consider cultural, institutional, and media influences on the development of gender related beliefs and attitudes
courses.course_syllabus:
The Study of Gender: Fundamental concepts in gender study; issues in the study of gender

Gender Development: Theories of gender development; gender identity development

Gender Stereotypes: Origins and implications of gender stereotypes

Gender and Cognitive Abilities: Gender differences in various cognitive abilities; implications of gender-related differences on the school experience

Gender as Social Performance: Gender differences in communication styles and emotional expression; gendered social behaviors

Gender and Interpersonal Relationships: Gender and friendship, courtship and marital relationship

Gender and Sexuality: Sexual orientation; gender differences in sexual attitudes

Gender and the Media: Media and gender socialization; gender representation in media

Gender and Violence: Violence in the daily lives of women and men; gender differences in expression of aggression

Gender and Work: Career expectations and opportunities; sexual harassment at work

Gender and Health: Gender role and health care; body image; mental health
courses.required_readings: Brannon, L. (2011). Gender: Psychological perspective. Allyn and Bacon.
courses.recommended_readings:
Cheung, F. M., & Halpern, D. F. (2010). Women at the Top: Powerful leader define success as work + family in a culture of gender. American Psychologist, 65, 182-193.

De Pater, I. E., Van Vianen, A. E. M., & Bechtoldt, M. N. (2010). Gender differences in job challenge: A matter of task allocation. Gender, Work and Organization, 17, 433-453.

Stone, J. P., & McBeath, M. K. (2010). Gender differences in distance estimates when exposed to multiple routes. Environment and Behavior, 42, 469-478.

Tsui, K. L., Chan, A. Y., So, F. L., & Kam, C. W. (2006). Risk factors for injury to married women from domestic violence in Hong Kong. Hong Kong Medical Journal, 12, 289-293.

Watkins, D., Dong, Q., & Xia, Y. (1997). Age and gender differences in the self-esteem of Chinese children. Journal of Social Psychology, 137, 374-379.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Emotion and Motivation
courses.description: This course discusses the theories and empirical findings on emotions and other related topics (such as subjective experience, happiness, life satisfaction and emotion states). Students will learn how emotions influence the ways we think and behave, the situations we seek, and the ways we make sense of our lives.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. understand, relate and apply the key emotion and motivation concepts to daily life

2. familiarize with the key classical and contemporary experimental studies and findings in emotion and motivation

3. conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during tutorial discussions, on emotion and motivation related topics

4. design, direct and regulate own study plan for problem-based learning, from identifying the problem, setting learning objectives, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what has been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Conceptual foundation of Emotion

2. Biology and Emotion

3. Cognition and Emotion

4. Family and Emotion

5. Aging and Emotion

6. Personality and Emotion

7. Self-regulation of Emotion

8. Nonconscious Emotion Regulation

9. Expression of Emotion, Facial Emotion

10. Culture and Emotion

11. Stress and Emotion

12. Emotion pathology
courses.required_readings: Gross, James.J. (2009). Handbook of Emotion Regulation (1st Ed). Guilford Press.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Abnormal Psychology
courses.description: Various types of psychological disorders falling under psychiatric nomenclature and other behavioural models. Theories and research concerning the origin, diagnosis and treatment of these disorders.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
Not for students who have taken SOWK2140.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Learn the basic concepts of abnormal psychology.

2. Learn how brain predispositions and upbringing experience interact to lead to mental disorders.

3. Learn to do detailed clinical case analysis according to the integrative perspective.

4. Develop insights into your own and others’ mental processes.

5. Learn to use E-journals and internet in pursuing personal interests in this field.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Brain plasticity, experience, and mental disorders

2. Stress and mental disorders

3. Diagnosing mental disorders

4. Anxiety disorders

5. Mood disorders

6. Somatoform and dissociative disorders

7. Substance-related disorders

8. Gender identity and sex-related disorders

9. Eating Disorders

10. Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders

11. Personality disorders

12. ADHD, autism and mental retardation
courses.required_readings: Butcher, J.N., Mineka, S., & Hooley, J.M. (2011). Abnormal Psychology: Core Concepts (2nd Ed.). Boston: Pearson.
courses.recommended_readings: There will be other assigned readings for different lectures and tutorials. Students will be taught to download most of these readings from E-journal.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Health Psychology
courses.description: This course provides an overview of health psychology and the role of health psychologists in clinical and research settings. It examines biological, psychological, and social factors in the conceptions of health and health related attitudes, beliefs and behaviors. Topics include health promotion, behavioral health and illness prevention, substance abuse, stress and coping, management of chronic and terminal illness, pain management, and health services. Students will gain an understanding of the theory and everyday life applications of health psychology in contemporary societies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. understand, relate and apply the key health psychological concepts to daily life

2. familiarize with the key classical and contemporary experimental studies and findings in health psychology

3. conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during tutorial discussions, on health psychology related topics

4. design, direct and regulate own study plan for problem-based learning, from identifying the problem, setting learning objectives, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what has been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems
courses.course_syllabus:
1. What is Health Psychology?

2. Health Promotion and Health Behavior Change

3. Stress

4. Coping with Stress

5. Pain and Discomfort

6. Health Enhancing Behaviors

7. Health Compromising Behaviors

8. Heart Disease, Hypertension, Stroke, and Diabetes

9. AIDS, leukemia, and rheumatoid arthritis

10. Health Services and Patient-Provider Relations

11. Management of Chronic Illness

12. Terminal Illness
courses.required_readings: Taylor, S. E. (2011). Health Psychology (8th edition). New York: McGraw Hill.
courses.recommended_readings: Books and journals articles will be suggested for different topics at the end of each class.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Professional Issues and Development in Mental Health Practice
courses.description: Issues of professional ethics, interdisciplinary approach and teamwork, professional development, and personal growth will be discussed with students as fundamentals in providing care to clients. A scientifically based psychosocial framework in conceptualizing and understanding individuals’ multi-faceted needs (physical and mental health, social and occupational needs) along with considerations of policy and structural issues to support individuals’ recovery will be discussed. Issues around diversity and mental health disparities are discussed to raise the consciousness of students.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Be familiar with the key concepts in mental health practice

2. Be able to weigh various perspectives underlying an ethical dilemma

3. Be aware of cultural diversity in mental health related issues

4. Be able to conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during in-class discussions, on mental health practice and related topics
courses.course_syllabus:
• Professional conduct and ethics

• Development as a mental health provider

• Models of mental health, recovery, and related practice

• Policies related to mental health service delivery

• Diversity and cultural competence

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Evidence-based Mental Health Practice
courses.description: This course will introduce the essence of evidence-based practice and stepped care model in the delivery of mental health services. Students will understand how evidence is built around a certain intervention approach and/or for specific mental disorders. The issue of evidence will be discussed from multiple perspectives, from various quantitative approaches to establish efficacy and effectiveness to qualitative accounts from various stakeholders, including individuals with lived experience of mental health issues. Issues on the implementation and dissemination of evidence-based practice in real life settings will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, you will be able to

a. Describe the basics of evidence-based practice and stepped care model in the delivery of mental health services

b. Describe the phenomena, cognitive-behavioral models, and interventions of common mental health problems

c. Demonstrate competence in quantitatively and qualitatively evaluating a treatment or intervention program.
courses.course_syllabus:
a. The fundamentals of evidence-based practice and stepped care model

b. The phenomena and diagnoses of common mental health problems

- Major depressive disorder

- Specific phobia

- Panic disorder (with agoraphobia)

- Generalized anxiety disorder

c. The low-intensity cognitive-behavioral treatment of common mental health problems

- Major depressive disorder

- Specific phobia

- Panic disorder (with agoraphobia)

- Generalized anxiety disorder

d. Issues of evidence-based practice in real life settings

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Counseling Theories and their Applications to Clinical, Career and Organizational Settings
courses.description: This course will examine some common counseling theories and their usefulness in and applications in, various domains (clinical interventions, career counseling at schools, talent development by human resources). Coaching and some organizational development applications will be discussed and external speakers will provide an applied perspective on the field.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the knowledge base of Counselling psychology

2. Develop critical thinking skills in Counselling psychology

3. Apply and relate Counselling psychology to interpersonal, career and organizational settings

4. Recognize the values in Counselling psychology

5. Gain effective communication skills

6. Gain insights about personal development in different contexts (school and organizational)
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Counseling: What is the field about, where is counseling used and what do counselors do?

2. Career Counseling in Schools and Elsewhere: Theories and practices in helping people find their interests

3. Executive Coaching – Counseling in business

4. Positive Psychology and counseling: The impact of positive psychology on counseling within organizations

5. Biological Bases for behavior: The impact of biology on counseling approaches

6. Clinical approaches I – Psychodynamic Therapy

7. Clinical approaches II – Brief Therapy

8. Clinical approaches III – Group Child and Family Therapy

9. Clinical approaches IV – Logotherapy and Gestalt Therapy

10. Clinincal approaches V – Reality Therapy

11. Clinincal approaches VI – Brief Therapy

12. Other modes of therapy (e.g., use of media in therapy/coaching)

13. Therapy Integration – current state of the field

2. Students’ reflection on the course

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Engagement and Assessment of Individuals with Common Mental Health Problems
courses.description: To effectively engage and assess individuals with common mental health difficulties, students will gain an understanding and competency in the application of “common factors” (e.g., active listening, rapport building, expression of empathy), knowledge in common mental health problems, and evidence-based interventions. The focus will be on training students on effective communication skills and assessment of individuals with anxiety and depression. Students will be trained on core skills of engagement, communication, and assessment through skills-based practices and role-plays. Students are expected to engage in self-practice self-reflection throughout the course by themselves or with their classmates. In order to qualify for practicum in guided self-help, students must pass the minimal competency requirements in conducting a complete assessment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC3730 & PSYC3740
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, you will be able to

a. Describe the background knowledge pertinent to the three sections of an assessment including information gathering, information giving, and shared decision making.

b. Acquire micro skills to engage a client and develop a therapeutic alliance.

c. Demonstrate competence in conducting a collaborative assessment for the low-intensity psychological treatment program for common mental health problems.

d. Demonstrate competence in delivering an assessment using a range of methods including face-to-face, telephone, and electronic communication.

e. Reflect upon the process and outcome of clinical work in relation to theory and research evidence.
courses.course_syllabus:
Evidence-based assessment and strategies

a. Information gathering

- The nature of chief complains and their impacts

- Risk assessment

- Outcome measures

- Past treatment experience, current treatments plan, and expectation

b. Information giving

- Problem statement

- Functional analysis with the ABC model

c. Shared decision making

- Treatment option and plan

- Homework assignment
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course Evaluation Questionnaire

2. Students’ reflection on the course
