courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Evidence Based Low Intensity Interventions for Common Mental Health Problems
courses.description: Based on the evidence-based approaches for treatment of individuals with mild to moderate levels of common mental health problems, students will gain competency on a range of these evidence-based interventions, particularly low intensity cognitive behavioral interventions. Emphasis is put on clinical skills building to develop students’ “specific factors” competencies in the provision of low-intensity cognitive behavioral interventions using the guided self-help approach. Students will be trained on core skills of guided self-help through skills-based practices and role-plays. Students are expected to engage in self-practice self-reflection throughout the course by themselves or with their classmates. In order to qualify for practicum in guided self-help, students must pass the minimal competency requirements in conducting a complete intervention using the guided self-help approach.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC3760
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, you will be able to

a. Demonstrate competence in planning a collaborative low-intensity psychological treatment programme for common mental health problems

b. Describe a range of evidence-based interventions and strategies to assist patients to manage their emotional distress and disturbance

c. Evaluate and use competently low-intensity basic, intervention-specific and problem-specific techniques such as behavioural activation, exposure, guided problem solving, and dealing with worry, according to individualised assessment and theoretical basis

d. Demonstrate competence in delivering low-intensity interventions using a range of methods including face-to-face, telephone and electronic communication

e. Evaluate the role of case management and stepped-care approaches to managing common mental health problems in primary care, including ongoing risk management appropriate to service protocols

f. Reflect upon the processes and outcome of clinical work in relation to theory and research evidence
courses.course_syllabus:
Evidence based interventions and strategies

- developing and maintaining a therapeutic alliance

- dealing with issues and events that disrupt the alliance

- planning a low intensity psychological treatment

- low intensity interventions

- behavioural activation

- guided self-help

- problem solving

- exposure

- sleep hygiene

Context of delivery

- case management

- stepped care

- risk management

- supporting low intensity interventions (face-to-face, telephone, email)

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Applied Psychology in Business
courses.description: The course covers the application of psychological knowledge in service and industrial operations. Topics include the psychological foundation of consumer behaviour and advertising, the psychological analysis of the interaction between sales personnel and customers, economic psychology, current motivational techniques for enhancing performance, team-building, the psychology of industrial relations, and other current topics. The course will give equal emphasis to theories and applications.

3. conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both on tests and during tutorial discussions, on Psychology-related topics

4. design, direct and regulate own study plan for problem-based learning, from identifying the problem to setting learning objectives and applying knowledge to future problems

courses.description:
This course helps students to apply psychology to tackle social issues. Students will learn about successful stories of psychology applications, and under the guidance of the teaching team, design and implement their own projects in an attempt to apply theories and findings of psychology to make an impact on people's lives and the society-at-large.
A problem-based learning approach will be implemented in this course. Under the framework of design thinking, students will identify the issue of interest and apply their psychological knowledge to create changes on the issues. Students will be engaged in a wide range of in-class discussions, problem-based activities, and self-reflection processes to facilitate their learning. Students are expected to go outside the classroom, connect with the potential stakeholders and discuss their proposal with them. By the end of the course, students are required to give a group presentation and submit a project proposal to consolidate their thinking and efforts and to reflect on the possibility of future actions.

Advisory: For Psychology Majors only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC1000 or UGED2581
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Success stories and psychology applications
2. Obstacles and challenges in applying psychology
3. The framework of Design Thinking: Inspiration, Definition, Prototyping, Testing, and Storytelling
4. Some successful cases adopting design thinking
5. Ethical issues involved in practices

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Practicum in Neuroscience and Psychology
courses.description:
This course provides students an opportunity to conduct research in a neuroscience laboratory. Students will gain hands-on experience in using neuroscience techniques available to conduct psychological research. Emphases will be placed on experiment programming, data collection, data analyses, results presentation, report writing and reflection papers under the guidance of a faculty member. Upon the completion of this course, students should be able to apply textbook knowledge to actual research, and identify the strengths and limitations of neuroscience techniques in psychological research. The experience would serve as a springboard for students to adopt neuroscience reasoning and techniques in any sub-fields of psychology research.

Advisory: For Psychology Major Year 2 & 3 students only.
courses.course_attributes:
Capstone Course
Experiential Learning Course
Internship
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To acquire the knowledge and skills in conducting a psychological experiment using a neuroscience technique and in presenting the findings.
2. To identify the strengths and weaknesses of using neuroscience techniques in psychological research.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Experiment programming
2. Physical principles behind a neuroscience technique (e.g., EEG, optical imaging, TMS, tDCS, fMRI)
3. Operation of a type of neuroscience equipment
4. Data collection
5. Data analyses
6. Result presentation and critique
7. The power and limitations of neuroscience techniques

1. Course Evaluation Questionnaire

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Practicum in Education and Human Development
courses.description:
This course introduces students to applied developmental settings such as schools, organizations that work with children and adolescents, and medical institutions such that they will have an opportunity to apply the theories and subject matter of developmental and educational psychology in the "real world". Students will arrange a practicum placement together with the course lecturer.

Advisory: For Psychology Majors only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGED2581, PSYC2530 or 2540 or 3540 or 3550, and permission of course teacher.
courses.course_attributes:
Capstone Course
Experiential Learning Course
Internship
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will:
1. Refresh, deepen, and broaden their understanding of concepts, theoretical perspectives, and empirical findings in educational and/or developmental psychology that are relevant to observations made and tasks/projects worked on at the placement site.
2. Apply their understanding of theory and research in psychology in general and educational and/or developmental psychology in particular to personal, organizational, and social issues.
3. Recognize and appreciate socio-cultural complexity and diversity.
4. Develop insights into their own and others’ behavior and psyche and employ effective strategies for self-management and self-improvement.
5. Emerge from the course with realistic ideas about how to implement their knowledge, skills, and values in psychology in a variety of applied settings.
6. Communicate effectively in a variety of formats.
courses.course_syllabus:
The focus of the course is on the practical nature of psychology. Therefore, there will be no formal lectures. Instead, the course will consist of the following activities:
Course Activities:
1. Preparatory meetings: Before starting the practicum, each student will meet with the field supervisor (usually together with the professor). During the meeting, the student should discuss with the field supervisor on their mutual expectations for the practicum, the kind of practical work available at the placement, and preparations that need to be made, etc. The student should also set his/her work schedule with the supervisor.
2. Practicum: Each student is expected to work for approximately 160 hours in total at the placement. A student should be at the placement for 2 full days per week. Each student should decide with the field supervisor as soon as possible a fixed weekly schedule for his/her work at the placement. A copy of the finalized schedule should be submitted to the professor for record. Throughout the semester, each student will receive supervision and advice from the field supervisor as well as the professor and the tutor.
3. Group discussions: There will be approximately biweekly group discussion sessions, each taking around 2.5 hours. Additional sessions may be held throughout the semester for guest speeches or near the end of the semester for oral presentations if needed.
Students are expected to openly share their experience working at different placements (e.g., any observations they make, any practical work they engage in, any difficulties or problems they encounter). It is essential that students learn from one another’s experience and feel free to seek as well as give advice and emotional support in a mutually understanding and helpful environment.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course Evaluation Questionnaire
2. Students’ reflection on the course
courses.required_readings: None. (note: Students do the practicum of various settings so no one-fill-all textbook for the course. Individual guidance will be given indeed.)

Experiential Learning Course
Internship

2. Understand and apply psychological principles to personal, social, and organizational issues.

3. Weigh evidence, tolerate ambiguity, act ethically, and reflect other values that are the underpinnings of psychology as a discipline.

4. Communicate effectively in a variety of formats.

6. Develop insight into their own and others’ behavior and mental processes and apply effective strategies for self-management and self-improvement.

7. Emerge through the course of the practicum with realistic ideas about how to implement their psychological knowledge, skills, and values in a variety of applied settings.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Practicum in Psychology and Health
courses.description:
This course focuses on training students in the application of theories and practice related to clinical and health psychology across social welfare, health, and other applied settings in the community. Students will be assigned a practicum placement by the course instructor.

Advisory: For Psychology Majors only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGED2581, PSYC2780 or 3700 or 3720 or 3730 or 3740, and permission of course teacher.
courses.course_attributes:
Capstone Course
Experiential Learning Course
Internship
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. understand, relate, and apply the key psychological concepts in applied settings
2. gain hands-on experience in applied settings
3. conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during weekly discussions, on health/clinical psychology-related topics
4. design, direct, and regulate one’s work plan, from generating original ideas, listing of possible plans, setting expected work outcomes, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what have been learned, to applying the knowledge in future encounter at applied settings
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Preparatory meeting: Students will contact their practicum supervisors before the beginning of the practicum. The format of this meeting may vary (phone or in-person), depending on the preference of the supervisors and arrangements made with the agencies. In short, students should discuss with their respective supervisors on their mutual expectations for the practicum, the kind of practical work available at their chosen setting, and preparation that needs to be made, etc. Students should also set their start date and work schedule with their supervisors. With the assistance of the supervisor and the instructor, each student will set goal(s) and identify a focus for his/her placement.
2. Practicum: Students are expected to work for at least 160 hours at their placement. Ideally, students should be at their placement for 2 full days or 4 half-days per week. In the case where there are two or more students assigned to the same setting, they should try to work on alternate days of the week. Students are advised to work out a detailed schedule with the supervisor at their placement as soon as possible. A copy of the schedule should be given to the instructor for record. In addition to their field supervisor, students will also receive supervision from the instructor.
3. Discussion group: Attendance is mandatory. The purpose of these 3-hour sessions, to be scheduled according to instructor and students’ schedule is to provide students with an opportunity to share their working experience in different settings, observations that they have made, any difficulties they may have encountered, and any issues that may have arisen in their work. These meetings will provide students with a safe environment to learn, seek advice, and obtain emotional support.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course Evaluation Questionnaire
2. Students’ reflection on the course
courses.required_readings:
Learning resources
As the practicum sites vary in the nature of work and clientele, specific readings related to the practicum may be assigned by the specific practicum supervisor to complement your hands-on experience. Students enrolling in the practicum must have completed the prerequisites set out for this course to have a basic foundation in clinical psychology, abnormal psychology, or health psychology. Recommended readings on ethics and basic counseling skills are listed to equip students with knowledge related to the general practice in mental health- and health-related settings.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Research Practicum
courses.description:
This course introduces students to research through working in one of the research centres or laboratories to conduct psychology studies in a scientific manner that they will have an opportunity to apply psychology research methods. Students will work on different aspects of the research process like literature review, research design, data collection, data analysis, results presentation and as well as report writing under the guidance of a faculty member. Upon completion of this course, students shall develop an overview of the research process on some well-defined research questions. Students are expected to apply various research skills and to learn the professional attitudes and ethical standards to be a researcher.

Advisory: For Psychology Majors only.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: PSYC1000 or UGEC2581 or UGED2581, and permission of course teacher.
courses.course_attributes:
Capstone Course
Experiential Learning Course
Internship
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. understand the steps in conducting psychological research and apply this to one's own topics of interest
2. gain hands-on experience in research settings
3. conceptualize, structure, and express research ideas, in written assignments, oral presentations, and during group discussions
4. plan and regulate one's own work in research settings, from initiating research proposal, planning experiments, to drafting research report
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Important characteristics of researchers
3. Obstacles and difficulties in conducting research
4. Attitudes and research ethics
5. Basic research techniques
6. Formulating research ideas
7. Revision of data analyses
8. Communicating research ideas and results appropriately
9. Presentation skills
10. Conclusion
courses.required_readings: To be advised by supervisor

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Undergraduate Practicum in Guided Self-Help
courses.description: Students will provide guided self-help services in community settings under the supervision of clinical psychologists. This practicum experience represents the culmination of knowledge and competencies that the students have developed towards assessment of common mental health difficulties and interventions using low-intensity interventions and guided self-help within the stepped care model. Students at the practicum settings will work as part of the team in providing evidence-based services to individuals with mild to moderate common mental health difficulties. Issues pertinent to service delivery such as risk management, medication, and multi-cultural competence are discussed to raise the awareness, sensitivity, and competence of students in providing services. The science and practice of adaptations during the service implementation to accommodate individuals from diverse social, cultural, health, economic, and occupational backgrounds as well as in-service settings with varied resources and community contexts will be introduced to enhance students’ critical appreciation of the knowledge, attitudes, and competencies required to support clients’ recovery in an inclusive, value-driven way. Students need to fulfill at least 160 hours on-site under the supervision of clinical psychologists and attend biweekly one-hour clinical skills supervision by the course instructor.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite(s): PSYC3730, 3740, 3760, 3770 and permission of course instructor
courses.course_attributes:
Capstone Course
Experiential Learning Course
Internship
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Conduct relevant assessments at applied settings
2. Provide guided self-help and other related tasks at applied settings
3. Learn to work as a team and seek proper supervision at applied settings
4. Conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during discussions
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Preparatory meeting: Students will contact their practicum supervisors before the beginning of the practicum. The format of this meeting may vary (phone or in-person), depending on the preference of the supervisors and arrangements made with the agencies. In short, students should discuss with their respective supervisors on their mutual expectations for the practicum, the kind of practical work available at their chosen setting, and preparation that needs to be made, etc. Students should also set their start date and work schedule with their supervisors.
2. Practicum: Students are expected to work for at least 160 hours at their placement. Ideally, students should be at their placement for 2 full days or 4 half-days per week. In the case where there are two or more students assigned to the same setting, they should try to work on alternate days of the week. Students are advised to work out a detailed schedule with the supervisor at their placement as soon as possible. A copy of the schedule should be given to the instructor for record.
3. Discussion group: Attendance is mandatory. The purpose of these sessions, to be scheduled according to instructor and students’ schedule is to provide students with an opportunity to develop their clinical skills and to share their working experience with each other.

1. Course Evaluation Questionnaire
2. Students’ reflection on the course
courses.required_readings: To be advised

courses.description:
This course extends students’ ideas developed in the course PSYC4900 “Psychology in Action I”. Building upon the framework of design thinking, students will implement the project by prototyping their proposed ideas and evaluate the effectiveness by appropriate methods and outcomes. By the end of the course, students are required to summarize their completed work in a group presentation and submit a project report to outline their whole progress of learning throughout these two courses.

Advisory: For Psychology Majors only.

1. The framework of Design Thinking: Inspiration, Definition, Prototyping, Testing, and Storytelling
2. Assessment of novelty, feasibility, and potential impact of the ideas
3. Implementation of ideas and evaluation of potential challenges and future directions
4. Communicating ideas in varied formats: Storytelling, publicizing and proposal writing

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Seminar in Research Methods I
courses.description: This course helps students to understand the concepts and methods of data analysis in social research. In particular, students will learn how to apply appropriate statistical methods in various research scenarios and how to interpret the results. The usage of statistical packages such as SPSS will be covered. Even though mathematical proofs and statistical derivations will be reduced to a minimum, having the knowledge of basic mathematics and matrix manipulations will be helpful.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology or MPhil-PhD Psychology or MSSc Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of this course, you will have a better understanding about the concepts and principles of statistical modeling and data analysis in general. Moreover, you should be more proficient in applying different statistical techniques such as correlation and multiple regression analysis, logistic regression, ANCOVA and MANOVA.
courses.course_syllabus:
Review of Basic Statistics

Correlation Coefficient

Measures of Association

Multiple Regression

Logistic Regression

MANOVA

Repeated Measures Analysis

Analysis of Covariance
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline.
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Statistics and Research Design in Psychological Science
courses.description: In this course students will learn to understand the logic, purpose and techniques of statistical analyses, particularly those for psychology, and learn the basic types of experimental designs (e.g., within-subjects designs vs. between-subjects designs) and know how to use them appropriately in various situations. Students will also learn to address the important issues in designing and conducting psychological experiments (e.g., Research ethics, Literature review, Control groups, Presentations). We will emphasize the understanding of logic and attempt to reduce load of memory.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will know the procedure to carry out statistical methods in psychology and be able to both use them in practical question and understand them in the scientific literature.
2. Students will understand the logic behind those procedures and know how to solve similar questions.
3. Students will know the basic types of experimental designs (e.g., within-subjects designs vs. between-subjects designs) and know how to use them appropriately in various situations.
4. Students will know how to address the important issues in designing and conducting psychological experiments (e.g., Research ethics, Literature review, Control groups, Presentations).
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Descriptive statistics
2. Normal Distribution and Hypothesis Testing
3. Z-test, Effect size, Power
4. t-test and ANOVA
5. Correlation, regression, and Chi-square test
6. Scientific thinking in Psychology
7. Developing research ideas
8. Experimental approaches
9. Control problem
10. Experimental design 1
11. Experimental design 2
12. Other research methods
13. Other issues (Ethics, Presentation, etc)
courses.required_readings:
Statistics for Psychology (5/E) by Arthur Aron, Elaine N. Aron, & Elliot Coups (2008)
Research In Psychology: Methods and Design (6/E) by C. James Goodwin (2009)

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Psychological Testing and Measurement
courses.description: This course is designed to cover the basic principles of psychological measurement and the techniques of test construction, administration, and validation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Able to understand the basic concepts and principles of psychological measurement.
2. Able to evaluate the quality of a psychological test scientifically.
3. Able to constract a test with desirable psychometric properties.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Levels of Measurement and Transformation of Measured Scores
3. Test Standardization and Norms
4. Correlations
5. Multiple-item Scaling
6. Theory of Summated Scores
7. Test Reliability and Classical Test Theory (Part 1)
8. Test Reliability and Classical Test Theory (Part 2)
9. Test Validity
10. Construct Validation and Factor Analysis
11. Item Analysis
12. Project Presentation
13. Course Examination

courses.description: In this capstone course, students will work in small groups to address an applied psychology topic that will utilize their skills and knowledge in psychology. Under the supervision of the course instructor, students will identify a social issue, conduct literature research to design an intervention to address the issue, carry out the intervention, and assess the effectiveness of the intervention. Students will document their process in an applied research report. At the completion of the course, students should be able to learn how to apply psychological knowledge and skills in addressing social issues.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Health Psychology
courses.description: This course provides an overview of health psychology and the role of health psychologists in clinical and research settings. It examines biological, psychological, and social factors in the conceptions of health and health related attitudes, beliefs and behaviors. Topics include health promotion, behavioral health and illness prevention, substance abuse, stress and coping, management of chronic and terminal illness, pain management, and health services. Students will gain an understanding of the theory and everyday life applications of health psychology in contemporary societies.

| 4. design, direct and regulate own study plan for problem-based learning, from identifying the problem, setting learning objectives, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what has been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems | |

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Educational Psychology
courses.description: This course introduces the application of theoretical principles and research findings from the field of psychology to educational settings. Topics to be covered include general instructional issues, learning and motivation, effective instruction, educating students with special needs, measurement and evaluation. Special emphasis is placed on the understanding and solution of educational problems in the local community.

II. Be able to discuss and explain some principles governing learning from a psychological perspective
III. Be able to critically examine educational research and their implications
IV. Be able to analyse and discuss educational issues in an informative fashion

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Industrial-organizational Psychology
courses.description: Work is an indispensable part of life. And the study of psychology at work is a domain of Industrial/ Organizational (I/O) psychology. This course focuses on the application of psychological methods and principles in understanding the world of work and work behaviors.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in Psychology programme
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Be knowledgeable of the topics, methodologies, essential concepts and findings in Industrial-organizational Psychology

2. Be able to reflect upon work related issues from a psychological perspective

3. Be able to recognize the values in industrial-organizational psychology
courses.course_syllabus:
| 1. Introduction | This is a broad overview of what I/O psychology is and its roots, early history and future development. |
| --- | --- |
| 2. Job analysis | This topic introduces the systematic study of a job’s task, the job analysis method and techniques, how job analysis relates to other personnel functions. |
| 3. Recruitment & Selection | This topic decomposes each step in selecting employees in detail. The strengths and weaknesses of the tools used in the selection process are examined. The guidance and regulations with regard to protection against discrimination in employment is discussed. |
| 4. Performance Appraisal | This lecture begins with the purposes of performance appraisals, then describes methods of various performance rating methods and discusses their advantages and disadvantages. It also delivers problems and pitfalls in appraisals. |
| 5. Training & Development | This topic discusses fundamental issues in the design of employee training programs. Components of a successful training program model will be identified. |
| 6. Motivation | This topic examines various theories of job motivation and their applications. The relationship between motivation and work performance will be illustrated. |
| 7. Positive & Negative Employee Attitudes | This topic is about the relationship between job satisfaction and organizational commitment and between employees’ job attitudes and work behaviors. Factors that can increase positive attitudes and behaviors will be illustrated. This topic also looks at different sources, measurement, effects, and coping strategies of worker stress. |
| 8. Group Processes and Work Teams | This lecture introduces central concepts of group dynamics at work settings including organizational socialization, group conformity, group cohesiveness, group conflicts, groupthink, and group polarization. The definition of work teams and the factors in leading effective work teams will be discussed. |
| 9. Leadership | This topic covers different theories of leadership and discusses their merits and demerits in depth. Applications of theories will be illustrated. |

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Biological Psychology
courses.description: This course addresses brain-behavior relationships. Emphasis will, therefore, be on the basic concepts of how the nervous system and the brain works in explanation for the behaviors, emotions and thoughts of human beings. The significance of studying and applying the neuropsychological concepts in daily life will be highlighted. It will also introduce some abnormal cognitive and emotional problems in relation to the malfunction of the brain.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To have basic understanding of some major concepts, theoretical perspectives and empirical findings in physiological psychology and neuropsychology.
2. To apply some basic neuropsychological principles to daily life experience, such as knowledge of brain function enhancing activities; precautions in encountering people suffering from brain disorders.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Neuronal System and Neural anatomy
3. Methods in Neuropsychology
4. Sensory Processing
5. Object Recognition & Spatial Processing
6. Emotion
7. Mid-Term Examination
8. Motor Control
9. Memory
10. Lauguage
11. Executive Function
12. Common Brain Disorders in Childhood and Adulthood
13. Final Examination
courses.required_readings:
Neil R. Carlson. (2009). Physiology of Behavior (10th ed.). Allyn & Bacon.
Zillmer E., Spiers M. & Culbertson B. (2008). Principles of Neuropsychology (2nd Edition). Belmont, CA: Wadsworth.
courses.recommended_readings: Recommended journal articles will be provided in lectures.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Cognitive Psychology
courses.description: This course aims at inspiring students to consider the question of how human being can dominate the earth from the perspective of cognitive psychology. Throughout the evolutionary history, our ancestors developed a repertoire of cognitive skills that are fundamental to human civilization. In some cases, we are different from other animals quantitatively (e.g., capacity of memory). In other cases, the ability concerned may be unique to us (e.g., communication with language). It is indeed difficult to imagine a life without these cognitive abilities. In lectures, students will be introduced with the basic concepts and findings about various cognitive abilities including cognition, sensation, perception, memory system, decision-making, and language-processing. In tutorials, they will receive trainings in conducting research in cognitive psychology.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand, relate and apply the key concepts of cognitive psychology to daily life.
2. Familiarize with the key classical and contemporary experimental studies and findings in cognitive psychology.
3. Conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during tutorial discussions, on topics related to cognitive psychology.
4. Design, direct and regulate own study plan for problem-based learning, from identifying the problem, setting learning objectives, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what has been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
2. Approaches to human cognition
3. Sensation and perception
4. Object and face recognition
5. Attention and performance
6. Memory system
7. Improving memory
8. Language processing
9. Solving problems
10. Judgment and decision making
11. Rationality
12. Cognition and emotion
13. Conclusion
courses.required_readings: Eysenck, M. W., & Keane, M. T. (2010). Cognitive psychology: A student’s handbook (6th Edition). New York: Psychology Press.
courses.recommended_readings: Recommended journal articles will be provided in lectures.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Developmental Psychology
courses.description: The goal of this course is to introduce students to the field of developmental psychology. We will explore theories, research methods, and research findings on physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development from early childhood to old age. We will also pay attention to the role of culture in shaping life-span development.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire a broad overview of life-span development
2. Understand and apply major concepts and research findings in developmental psychology to everyday life
3. Cultivate awareness of diversity and critical thinking through analyzing real-life issues in relation to developmental psychology
4. Promote personal growth through reflecting on one’s own development
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Theories of human development
2. Research methods in developmental psychology
3. Physical and cognitive development during childhood
4. Psychosocial development during childhood
5. Physical and cognitive development during adolescence
6. Family relations during childhood and adolescence
7. Peer relations during childhood and adolescence
8. Self and gender development
9. Moral development
10. Achievement motivation and work
11. Social relations during adulthood
12. Special topics on emerging adulthood and aging
13. Dying, death, and grieving
courses.required_readings: Boyd, D., & Bee, H. (2012). Lifespan Development (6th Ed.). Boston: Pearson.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Social Psychology
courses.description: This course provides a broad survey of the field of social psychology. After reviewing key theoretical and methodological approaches in the field, students will be exposed to different topic areas in social psychology, such as the self, group processes, interpersonal relationship, social influence, social cognition, aggression, and altruism. The course also incorporates cross-cultural perspective in discussing these topics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand key ideas and research findings in social psychology
2. Understand how research in social psychology is carried out
3. Apply theories and methods of social psychology in everyday life
4. Clearly communicate issues relevant to social psychology
courses.course_syllabus:
1. social group
2. interpersonal attraction
3. interpersonal relationships
4. self
5. social influence
6. persuasion
7. attitudes and behavior
8. causal attribution
9. social judgement
10. stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination
11. helping, hurting, and cooperating
courses.required_readings: Aronson, E., Wilson, T., & Akert, R. (2009). Social Psychology (7th edition, Global edition). MA: Pearson/Allyn and Bacon.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Abnormal Psychology
courses.description: Dramatic advances have occurred in the past two decades in the study of psychopathology. Human genome has been fully sequenced, the technologies of neuroimaging have made it possible for researchers to observe a brain in action in living people, and psychology has entered the Decade of the Mind. In this new decade, psychology has been re-defined as a science examining how human mind works in general. Abnormal psychology, on the other hand, specializes in understanding how human mind works when it goes haywire. This course is designed to provide you with the most updated knowledge in the field of psychopathology. You will learn about the key concepts of mental disorders, how mental predispositions and upbringing experience interact in the development of various mental disorders, how human mind works in different mental disorders, and more importantly, how you can continue to learn about the science of psychopathology on your own after you have completed the course. After all, learning is about “learning how to learn.”
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Familiarize with the DSM system for classifying and diagnosing different mental disorders.
2. Understand the development of different mental disorders.
3. Apply what have learnt in this course in analyzing real clinical cases.
4. Pursue own study interests and develop own study topics in abnormal psychology.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Brain plasticity, experience, and mental disorders
2. Diagnosing mental disorders
3. Stress, distress and mental disorders
4. Anxiety disorders
5. Mood disorders
6. Somatoform and dissociative disorders
7. Substance-related disorders
8. Gender identity and sex-related disorders
9. Eating Disorders
10. Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders
11. Personality disorders
12. ADHD, autism and mental retardation

Andreasen, N.C. (2001). Brave New Brain: Conquering Mental Illness in the Era of the Genome. New York: Oxford University Press.
Barlow, D., & Durand, V.M. (2012). Abnormal Psychology. NY: Thomson Learning.
Blaney, P.H. & Millon, T. (eds.) (2009). Oxford Textbook of Psychopathology. NY: Oxford University Press.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Personality Psychology
courses.description: This course presents the major theoretical approaches to personality and the basic techniques utilized to assess personality differences. The focus is on everyday life applications, empirical evidence in support and against the theories, and the design, application, and interpretation of personality questionnaires.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1: familiarize with the key classical and contemporary experimental studies and findings in personality psychology
2: understand, relate and apply the key personality psychological concepts to daily life
3: conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during tutorial discussions, on personality psychology related topics
4: design, direct and regulate own study plan on personality psychology, from identifying the problem, setting learning objectives, researching on relevant information, reflecting on what has been learnt, to applying the knowledge to future problems
courses.course_syllabus:
1. What is personality?
2. How do we go about studying personality?
3. How do we describe personality? Types, traits & interactionism
4. Biological Processes I
5. Biological Processes II
6. Psychodynamic perspective I
7. Psychodynamic perspective II
8. Neoanalytic perspective
9. Learning perspective
10. Phenomenological perspective I
11. Phenomenological perspective II
12. Cognitive self-regulation perspective I
13. Cognitive self-regulation perspective II
courses.required_readings: Carver, C. S. & Scheier, M. F. Perspectives on Personality (7th edition) Boston: Allyn & Bacon.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Independent Study in Cognitive Science
courses.description: This course is an application of the student-oriented method of teaching to psychological research on an approved topic. Students are required to do empirical research on topics related to current psychological issues under intensive guidance of a teacher. The requirements include reviewing literatures, developing research hypotheses, and writing research reports.

For students in MA Psychology
Prerequisite: PSYC5110
courses.learning_outcomes:

2. Apply scientific methods in psychology to research

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Independent Study in Human Development
courses.description: In this course, students can apply their knowledge in both theory and research related to psychology of human development. Students will conduct a study related to developmental psychology under intensive supervision of a teacher. The research project includes the following parts: literature review, conceptualization of research questions and hypotheses, data collection and analysis, and research report writing. Students may apply different research methods in their project, including both qualitative and quantitative methods.

For students in MA Psychology
Prerequisite: PSYC5110
courses.learning_outcomes:

2. Be familiarized with writing research reports
3. Be able to apply the research knowledge and techniques to both academic and applied settings

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Independent Study in Social Psychology
courses.description: Independent Study in Social Psychology is a capstone course for students to apply their knowledge in both theory and research of social psychology in conducting their own independent project. Students are required to do research on topics related to social psychology under intensive guidance of a teacher. The requirements include reviewing literatures, conceptualizing and designing research hypotheses, collecting and analyzing data, and writing research reports. Research methods may include archival analyses, interviews, survey questionnaire, experiments or field studies, adopting either a qualitative or a quantitative approach.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in MA Psychology
Prerequisite: PSYC5110
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will be able to transform a conceptual idea to a testable research question in the field of social psychology
2. Students will be able to draw evidence-based conclusions and inferences in the research field of social psychology by conducting systematic and scientific analyses
3. The research skills learned in the course will be applicable to both academic research and applied settings (e.g., educational institutions) in particular to organizational studies and community research

The independent study will include the following parts: literature review, design of research questions and hypotheses, data collection and analysis, and report writing. Students enrolled in this course may apply different research methods in their work, including both qualitative and quantitative methods in mental health studies.

2. Students will be able to apply different research methods in studying mental health issues

courses.title: Major Psychological Approaches

Professor HUANG Liqiang,

courses.description: The course will overview the areas of social and personality psychology, cognition, and lifespan developmental psychology. For each area, current theories and research methods, as well as recent findings and controversies, will be presented. Research students are required to take this general seminar before taking any of the more in-depth content-related graduate seminars in psychology. Culture, broadly defined, will be integrated into the content of the course across areas.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Seminar in Research Methods II
courses.description: This course is the continuation of Research Methods I (PSYC5010). The course objective is to understand the concepts and methods of data analysis in social science research. In particular, students will learn how to apply appropriate statistical methods in various research scenarios and how to interpret the results. Even though mathematical proofs and statistical derivations will be reduced to a minimum, having the knowledge of basic mathematics and matrix manipulations will be helpful. Various statistical software programs (such as EQS, HLM) in addition to SPSS will be introduced and the ability to use these programmes for data analysis is important.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology or MPhil-PhD Psychology or PhD Clinical Psychology or PsyD Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of this course, you will have a better understanding about the concepts and principles of statistical modeling and data analysis in general. Moreover, you should be more proficient in applying different statistical techniques such as analysis of covariance, factor analysis, structural equation modeling, hierarchical linear modeling, and log linear modeling.
courses.course_syllabus:
MANOVA

Repeated Measures Analysis

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Special Topics in Clinical Practices
courses.description: This advanced course in clinical practice encompasses specialty modules in a diversified spectrum covering topics and areas that graduates may encounter in local service settings. There are essentially four learning modules covering Violence, Behavioural Excess, Medical Psychology and Forensic Psychology. Students will learn about the theoretical knowledge base, current clinical and community intervention approaches, as well as information on local practice and resources.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should:

1. be informed of the most current theories, scientific foundation, evaluation, intervention and community resources relating

to major areas including intimate partner violence, sexual violence, substance abuse, common behavioural excess,

clinical and applied psychology in medical setting and forensic psychology,

2. become more informed to the processes of, and the sociocultural values in, applying their knowledge and intervention

skills in these areas,

3. become more sensitive to the social, cultural, ethical and diversity issues pertaining to the specialty areas.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Anger, hostility and aggression

2. Intimate partner violence

3. Child abuse: physical, sexual and psychological

4. Elderly abuse

5. Sexual Violence: from indecency to rape

6. Substance abuse: the new drug scene in Hong Kong

7. Behavioural excess problems: gambling, internet addiction and sexual compulsion

8. Suicide, para-suicide and homicide

9. Medical problems: chronic illnesses, pain, clinical oncology, palliative care, physical rehabilitation and HIV

10. Paraphilias and paraphilic disorders

11. Treatment of sexual offenders including risk assessment

12. Forensic Psychology: expert witness in court, fitness to plead and writing of forensic reports

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.description: Students may select a special topic in psychology and pursue an independent study in consultation with and under the supervision of one of the faculty members. The topic and content of the study will be individually determined. This course may be repeated for a maximum of 6 units.

2. formulate research questions and hypotheses,
3. design scientific experiments and studies, and
4. review existing literature in a critical manner.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Ethics and Professional Issues
courses.description: This course introduces students to the fundamentals of professional and ethical practice as clinical psychologists. References will be made to the most current international perspectives and codes of professional conduct to inform our understanding of best practices as scientist-practitioners. Topics covered in this module include local professional practice guidelines, international codes of conduct, the scientist-practitioner model, evidence-based practices, ethical and legal issues in assessment and research, diversity and multicultural considerations, and professional development issues. This course serves as an orientation to the profession of clinical psychology for new trainees.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should:
1. understand what it means to practice clinical psychology in a professional manner based on codes and standards
established internationally, as well as an understanding for issues specific to professional practice in Hong Kong,
2. be able to apply core ethical principles to clinical practice,
3. be aware of various potential ethical dilemmas and be able to resolve these dilemmas using the appropriate ethical
decision-making strategies,
4. understand the importance of developing and maintaining professional knowledge, skills and competencies, and
5. possess good insight in their ethical obligations as professional clinical psychologists.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Codes of Professional Conduct
2. The Scientist-Practitioner Model
3. Empirically Supported Treatments (ESTs)
4. Evidence-based Practices
5. Potential ethical issues in clinical practice
6. Resolving ethical dilemmas
7. Continuous professional development
8. Advancement of the profession of clinical psychology as an ethical obligation

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Research Issues in Clinical Psychology
courses.description: This seminar addresses methodological issues and strategies in clinical research. Major topics include principles and practices of clinical research; basic concepts and design of clinical measures; sources of artifact and bias in clinical research; analysis and interpretation of clinical research data; and ethical issues raised by clinical research.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of this course, students will have a better understanding about the concepts and principles of statistical modeling and data analysis in general. Moreover, students should be more proficient in applying different statistical techniques such as analysis of covariance, factor analysis, structural equation modeling, hierarchical linear modeling, and log linear modeling on different areas of clinical psychology.
courses.course_syllabus:
MANOVA

Repeated Measures Analysis

Analysis of Covariance

Exploratory Factor Analysis

Confirmatory Factor Analysis

Structural Equation Modeling

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Neuropsychology Assessment
courses.description: This seminar addresses the application of neuropsychology for clinical assessment. Emphasis will be on the examination of the effects of CNS on the behaviours of individuals and the cognitive disorders associated with various brain disorders. Several widely used instruments (i.e., tests and test battery) which measure a variety of neuropsychological disorders will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to:
1. acquire fundamental understanding of some basic but important concepts and theories in clinical neuropsychology,
2. learn about the value and application of clinical neuropsychological assessment,
3. learn about the neuropsychological tests for Chinese population,
4. acquire the basic concept on results interpretation and report writing.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Clinical Neuropsychology & Basic Neuroanatomy
2. Memory & Its Assessment
3. Language & Its Assessment
4. Executive Functions & Its Assessment
5. Principles of Neuropsychological Assessment

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Writing and Presentation
courses.description: This course will explore various types of writing as well as techniques to maximize effectiveness in oral presentations essential for psychology for graduate students. Topics to be covered include how to write thesis proposals, grant proposals, empirical studies, manuscript reviews, and review articles. We will also explore techniques for effective critiquing of manuscripts, writing clearly and concisely, understanding and incorporating APA style, and avoiding plagiarism. In addition, oral presentation skills will be overviewed, with opportunities for all students to practice presenting their own research.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology or MPhil-PhD Psychology or PhD Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be expected to:
- acquire the basic rules and skill in writing and presentation in psychology
- effectively assess and distinguish journal papers and other works in psychology
- grasp the writing and presentation skills and use these skills in the research career
courses.course_syllabus:
APA style

Plagiarism & Paraphrasing

Review paper writing

Journal reviews

Writing in English

Basic journal article writing

Getting published

courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Engagement and Motivation in Organizations
courses.description: This is the first course of a series of two courses in organizational psychology. Topics covered in this course include: job attitudes, work motivation, stress, job enrichment, communication, decision making, and conflict management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology or MPhil-PhD Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to:
1. Critically review and consolidate theories and empirical findings in organizational psychology at an individual level (e.g., employee
engagement, motivation, citizenship behaviors, stress and counter-productive work behaviors), a group level (e.g., team
composition/diversity, mental models, group decision making and leadership) and an organizational level (e.g., organizational
culture and organizational learning).
2. Critically evaluate and develop independent views on theories and empirical findings in organizational psychology at individual,
group and organizational levels.
3. Make informed judgments on how theories and empirical findings in organizational psychology could be applied in work settings.
courses.course_syllabus:
Work motivation (I): Overview & conceptualization
Work motivation (II): Goal-setting theory, social cognitive theory, & other major theories
Job attitudes (I): Job satisfaction, performance, & related concepts
Job attitudes (II): Job attitudes & withdrawal behavior in the workplace
Conducting survey research in organizations
Stress & burnout in the workplace
Leadership, coaching, & performance
Negotiation & conflict management
Cultural diversity in the workplace
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Leadership and Group Dynamics

meetings.instructor:
Dr. CHAN Tak Chun, 
Professor HUI Chi Chiu Harry

courses.description: This is the second course of a series of two courses in organizational psychology that provides a critical review of interpersonal, group, and organizational level issues in organizations. Topics covered include: groups dynamics, leadership and management, organizational development, and cross-cultural issues in organizational psychology.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology or MPhil-PhD Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to:
1. Critically review and consolidate theories and empirical findings in organizational psychology at an individual level (e.g., citizenship behaviors, and counter-productive work behaviors), a group level (e.g., team composition/diversity, mental models, group decision making and leadership) and an organizational level (e.g., organizational culture and organizational learning).
2. Critically evaluate and develop independent views on theories and empirical findings in organizational psychology at individual, group and organizational levels.
3. Make informed judgments on how theories and empirical findings in organizational psychology could be applied in work settings.
courses.course_syllabus:
Typologies and outcomes of conflicts
Intractable conflicts: Vicious cycles
Cognitive biases in a conflict
Apology and forgiveness
Leadership overview
Leadership when treated as a social construct
Understanding power and effective leadership
Leadership psychology and behavioral manifestations
Leadership in practice and how it develops over time

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Organizational Placement I
courses.description: Students will be placed to major organizations for internship training for 500 hours. They will work on a specific project in the organization under the joint supervision of a field supervisor of the host organization and a teacher from the Division.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this practicum, students are expected to:
1. acquire major concepts and theoretical perspectives in IO psychology
2. apply theoretical perspectives in IO psychology to personal, social, and organizational issues
3. develop critical thinking skills to make reflection on other values that are the underpinnings of psychology as a discipline
4. conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during discussions,
on IO psychology-related topics
5. develop positive values on respecting the complexity of sociocultural diversity develop self-management skills by means
of applying effective strategies for self-improvement attain personal growth through engaging in the practicum with
realistic ideas about how to implement the psychological knowledge, skills, and values in a variety of applied settings
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Practicum: Students are expected to work for at least 500 hours at their placement or placements. Usually the longest placements will be during the summer between the first and second year of the MPhil program. Ideally, students should be at their placement for 5 full days per week. Students are advised to work out a detailed schedule with the supervisor at their placement as soon as possible. A copy of the schedule should be given to the instructor for record. In addition to their field supervisor, students will also receive supervision from the instructor.
2. Discussion group: This will be held once a week or every other week during the summer placement. Attendance is mandatory. The purpose of these 2- to 3-hour sessions is to provide students with an opportunity to share their experience working in different settings, observations that they have made, any difficulties they may have encountered, and any issues that may have arisen in their work. These meetings will provide students with a safe environment to learn, seek advice and obtain emotional support.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcome to give comments and feedback at any time during the class. Stop by to talk to the instructor to do so. You can also send an email.
courses.required_readings: There are no required readings for the course at this time. Occasionally an article may be handed out for you to read if it is deemed relevant to the discussion at hand.
courses.recommended_readings: There are no required readings for the course at this time. Occasionally an article may be handed out for you to read if it is deemed relevant to the discussion at hand.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Organizational Placement II
courses.description: Students will be placed to major organizations for internship training for 500 hours. They will work on a specific project in the organization under the joint supervision of a field supervisor of the host organization and a teacher from the Division.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this practicum, students are expected to:
1. acquire major concepts and theoretical perspectives in IO psychology
2. apply theoretical perspectives in IO psychology to personal, social, and organizational issues
3. develop critical thinking skills to make reflection on other values that are the underpinnings of psychology as a discipline
4. conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during discussions,
on IO psychology-related topics
5. develop positive values on respecting the complexity of sociocultural diversity develop self-management skills by means
of applying effective strategies for self-improvement attain personal growth through engaging in the practicum with
realistic ideas about how to implement the psychological knowledge, skills, and values in a variety of applied settings
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Practicum: Students are expected to work for at least 500 hours at their placement or placements. Usually the longest placements will be during the summer between the first and second year of the MPhil program. Ideally, students should be at their placement for 5 full days per week. Students are advised to work out a detailed schedule with the supervisor at their placement as soon as possible. A copy of the schedule should be given to the instructor for record. In addition to their field supervisor, students will also receive supervision from the instructor.
2. Discussion group: This will be held once a week or every other week during the summer placement. Attendance is mandatory. The purpose of these 2- to 3-hour sessions is to provide students with an opportunity to share their experience working in different settings, observations that they have made, any difficulties they may have encountered, and any issues that may have arisen in their work. These meetings will provide students with a safe environment to learn, seek advice and obtain emotional support.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcome to give comments and feedback at any time during the class. Stop by to talk to the instructor to do so. You can also send an email.
courses.required_readings: There are no required readings for the course at this time. Occasionally an article may be handed out for you to read if it is deemed relevant to the discussion at hand.
courses.recommended_readings: There are no required readings for the course at this time. Occasionally an article may be handed out for you to read if it is deemed relevant to the discussion at hand.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Psychological Assessment at Work
courses.description: This course covers assessing, interpreting, and communicating individual differences for a variety of work-related purposes including selection and development of skills, abilities, personality, motivation, and interests. Both classical and modern measurement theories and their respective areas of application will be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this practicum, students are expected to:
1. understand the basics of psychometric theory.
2. understand the scientific, theoretical, empirical, and contextual bases of psychological assessment.
3. evaluate critically the multiple roles, contexts, and relationships within which clients and psychologists function, and the reciprocal impact of these roles, contexts, and relationships on assessment activity.
4. establish, maintain, and understand the collaborative professional relationship that provides a context for all psychological activities including psychological assessment.
5. Apply technical skills that include
a. understanding and selection of appropriate assessment methods
b. effective application of the assessment procedures
c. data gathering, integration of information, inference, and analysis
d. communication of findings and development of recommendations to address problems and goals
e. provision of feedback that is understandable, useful, and responsive to the client, regardless of whether the client is an individual, group, organization, or referral source
courses.course_syllabus:
Contemporary issues in assessment
Career interests
Cognitive
Personality
Integrity
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Learning and Development
courses.description: This course provides a critical review of the psychological issues in learning and development. Topics covered include: training needs assessment, psychological principles to enhance training, types of trainings, coaching and mentoring, technology enhanced training, evaluation of training programmes.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
a. Understand, relate and apply key learning and development theories and concepts to applied situations
b. Become familiar with the key classical and contemporary theories and practices of learning and development
c. Conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during seminar discussions, on learning and development related topics.
courses.course_syllabus:
Training needs assessment
Psychological principles to enhance learning & transfer
Evaluation of training
Instructional approaches:
(i) Technology-Based Training
(ii) Behavior modeling training; Team training
(iii) Coaching & mentoring; 360-degree feedback
(iv) “Alternative” or “new age” techniques; Adventure/outdoor training
Organization development
Further applications of training & development
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Seminar in Consumer Psychology
courses.description: This course covers fundamental issues in the psychology of consumer behaviour and advertising. Topics covered include: consumer information processing, consumer decision-making, customer satisfaction, psychology of customer service, attitudes and consumer behaviour, personality and consumer behaviour, social processes in consumer psychology, and psychology of advertising.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this seminar, students are expected to be:
1. Familiarized with major theories and current research in consumer psychology.
2. Able to identify and evaluate critically major issues in current consumer research.
3. Able to make informed judgments on how to apply relevant psychological concepts and research methodologies to address real
world marketing and consumption issues.
courses.course_syllabus:
Consumer & marketing research
Consumer decision making
Customer satisfaction & service quality
Consumer attitudes, values, life styles, & market segmentation
Effective persuasion and selling
Psychology of advertising
Promotional strategies
Environmental and social influence (Atmospherics; social influence, trends)
Cultural differences & consumer psychology
Consumer psychology & the Internet
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Seminar in Professional Issues
courses.description: This course will focus on the general professional codes of practice and ethical dilemmas for the practice of industrial-organizational psychology. It also explores the role of industrial-organizational psychologists in general practice, and in team work with other related professionals.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
a. Become familiar with the key classical and contemporary approaches to dealing with ethical issues that may come up on the job
for an I/O Psychologist who is a practitioner
b. Understand, relate and apply ethical concepts to applied situations involving complex organizational problems
c. Conceptualize, structure, articulate and present original ideas, both in written assignments and during seminar discussions, on
Ethics-in-I/O-related topics
courses.course_syllabus:
Legal environment and ethics guidelines
Discussion of cases regarding professional and ethical issues

courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Psychopathology
courses.description: This course introduces students to the key concepts and issues related to various mental disorders. Students will learn about the clinical phenomenology of different mental disorders and how these disorders are classified and diagnosed according to the DSM system. Throughout the course, students will learn to integrate research findings from bio-psycho-social domains and develop an integrative perspective in understanding the development of different mental disorders.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Psychology or MSSc Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the key concepts and issues related to various mental disorders

2. Familiarize with the clinical phenomenology of different mental disorders and how these disorders are classified and

diagnosed according to the DSM systems

3. Learn how bio-psycho-social variables interact in the development of various mental disorders

4. Do detailed clinical case analysis according to the integrative bio-psycho-social perspective
courses.course_syllabus:
Understanding Psychopathology from an Integrative Model

Diagnosing Mental Disorders

Stress, Emotional Distress, and Mental Disorders

Anxiety Disorders

Mood Disorders

Somatoform and Dissociative Disorders

Substance-related Disorders

Eating Disorders

Gender Identity and Sexual Disorders

Schizophrenia and other Psychotic Disorders

Personality Disorders

Childhood Disorders

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Health and Community Psychology
courses.description: This course provides a fundamental background in health and community psychology. Students will have the opportunity to critically examine and evaluate conceptual, methodological, and research issues that are germane in health and community psychology. New developments in these areas will be covered to equip students to lead the field. Focus will be on the synthesis and integration of the two disciplines within a person-in-environment perspective. Students are expected to evaluate issues not only at the individual level, but as well as within the ecology, including groups, settings, communities, cultures, etc. Furthermore, prevention, intervention, and rehabilitation are equally emphasized. It is the aim that students will have a fundamental understanding of major health and community psychology concepts and be able to conceptualize various health issues and formulate sound interventions in an ecological perspective.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Psychology or MSSc Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Demonstrate familiarity with the major concepts, theoretical perspectives, empirical findings and recent trends in health and community psychology.
2. Respect and use critical and creative thinking, skeptical inquiry, and scientific approach to understand the dynamics between people’s health behaviors and their communities.
3. Understand how personal, social, societal, and environmental factors contribute to people’s health behaviors.
4. Communicate effectively in a variety of formats and to a variety of audience.
5. Recognize, understand, and respect the complexity of sociocultural diversity and its influence on health behaviors.
6. Emerge from the course with realistic ideas about how to implement their psychological knowledge, skills, and values in public and community health settings.
courses.course_syllabus:
Shifting our agenda and approach

Health inequalities and social justice

Prevention and promotion

Digital health

Individual level behavior change theories

Ecological and community-based models

Recovery in mental illness vs. recovery from mental illness

Pain management and mindfulness

Social marketing on health promotion

CP’s role in community psychology

Service planning & program evaluation

Putting it all together

Grant Proposal Idea Presentations

Bickman, L. (2020). Improving Mental Health Services: A 50-Year Journey from Randomized Experiments to Artificial Intelligence and Precision Mental Health. *Administration and Policy in Mental Health and Mental Health Services Research*, 1-49.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Intelligence Assessment
courses.description: This course examines the theoretical, practical and cross-cultural problems in the assessment of intellectual and adaptive functioning. Both the clinical and psychometric approaches will be used. Emphasis will be placed on clinical interview, history-taking and other assessment techniques, test administration, scoring, results interpretation and report writing. A number of the widely used instruments in Hong Kong will be covered, and teaching and learning will take the form of interactive lectures and hands-on experiential learning.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to:

1. acquire fundamental understanding of major concepts and theories in intelligence and its assessments.

2. be fluent in administering the locally validated intellectual assessment tools (e.g. WISC-IV(HK) and WAIS-IV(HK), as well as adaptive functioning scales.

3. acquire basic skills in assessment profile interpretation and report writing as relevant to clinical applications.
courses.course_syllabus:
Major concepts and topics:

1. Introduction to intelligence and intellectual assessment

2. Assessment for adults and clinical applications

3. WAIS-IV(HK) – Testing skills I & II

4. WAIS-IV(HK) – Profile interpretation and report writing

5. Assessment for children and clinical applications

6. WISC-IV(HK) – Testing skills I & II

7. WISC-IV(HK) – Profile interpretation and report writing

8. Other Intellectual and Adaptive Functioning assessment tools
courses.required_readings:
Bruininks, R.H., Woodcock, R.W., Weatherman, R.E., & Hill, B.K. (1996). *Scales of Independent Behavior – Revised* (SIB-R). Itasca, Illinois: Riverside.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Assessment of Psychopathology and Personality
courses.description: This course focuses on the theoretical, practical and cross-cultural issues related to the assessment of psychopathology and personality. Students will be exposed to a variety of clinical evaluation protocols used for the collection of data in order to evaluate the psycholopathological status of an individual. They will learn about the application of these techniques to a wide range of clinical psychological problems as stipulated in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual for Mental Disorder Version 5 (DSM-V). These include mental state examination, test administration and interpretation, diagnostic decision making, integration of material derived from patient history and other sources, and comprehensive case conceptualization.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students should:

1. gain an understanding of how psychopathology is conceptualised and assessed,

2. have a working knowledge of current assessment and evaluation methods in psychopathology, their procedures and

caveats,

3. be informed about some of the adjunct evaluative and diagnostic tools such as the Chinese Minnesota Multiphasic

Personality Inventory-2 (CMMPI-2), the Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory-III (MCMI-III), Structured Interview for DSM-IV

(SCID), Composite International Diagnostic Interview (CIDI), Anxiety Disorder Interview Schedule for DSM-IV (ADIS) and

other self-rating and clinician-rated inventories as appropriate,

4. attain competence in clinical interviewing skills augmented by formalized assessment procedures, diagnosis and

differential diagnosis in accordance with the DSM-V, comprehensive case conceptualisation, formulation of

psychopathology and clinical report writing.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The clinical examination protocol,

2. A historical perspective of psychopathology and personality with reference to Freud, Adler, Watson, Pavlov, Skinner,

Bandura, Mischel, Rogers, Zuckerman, Sheldon, Cattell, Eysenck, Kelly, Tellegen, Plomin, McCrae and Costa, etc.

3. Personality assessment methods with particular reference to the CMMPI-2, the MCMI-III, SCID, CIDI, ADIS, and other self-

rated and clinician-rated scales,

4. Introduction to psychodiagnosis and differential diagnosis,

5. Integration of information, clinical data and assessment results leading to a clinical formulation of psychopathology, and

6. Assessment-informed intervention planning.
