courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Intervention Seminar I: Behavioural and Cognitive Therapies
courses.description: The course will serve as the first introduction to behavioural and cognitive therapies and emphasize both theoretical and practical training. It aims at training students basic competence to begin practising behavioural and cognitive therapies for adult psychological/psychiatric disorders. In the first part of the course, the general procedure of behavioural and cognitive therapies will be discussed, while in the second part, the application of behavioural and cognitive therapies to specific disorders, e.g., depression, anxiety disorders, substance-related disorders, personality disorders, and psychotic disorders, etc., will be elaborated. A substantial proportion of time during class will be allocated to discussing simulated therapy sessions on videotapes. The students are expected to do their own readings before coming to class. They will be required to make presentations on the application of behavioural and cognitive therapies to specific disorders, as well as on intervention studies regarding their efficacy and effectiveness.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to develop basic competence to begin practising behavioural and cognitive therapies for adult psychiatric disorders. Upon completion of the course, students should learn the general procedure of behavioural and cognitive therapies and their application to various disorders, e.g., depression, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, substance-related disorders, and psychotic disorders, etc.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of behavioural and cognitive therapies

2. Behavioural and cognitive assessment

3. Identification, evaluation and modification of automatic thoughts, intermediate beliefs, and core belief

4. Behavioural experiment, graded exposure, homework

5. Relaxation training, social skills training, problem-solving skills training

6. Termination, and relapse prevention

7. Behaviour therapy/modification

8. Application to different disorders, e.g., depression, anxiety disorders, personality disorders, substance-related disorders,

psychotic disorders, etc.

9. Theoretical integrative overview, & other new developments

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Intervention Seminar II: Working with Children and Adolescents
courses.description: The course will emphasize both theoretical and practical training on work with children and adolescents. It first starts with a discussion on developmental psychopathology. Then, the major focus of the course would aim at training students basic competence to perform intake diagnostic interview, assessment, diagnostic formulation, case conceptualization, and treatment planning, as well as to practise psychological intervention in treating various childhood and adolescent psychiatric disorders, such as autism spectrum disorders, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, oppositional defiant disorder, conduct disorder, anxiety disorders, and depressive disorders, etc., as illustration of the treatment processes. The course ends at discussing how to match and fine-tune common treatment processes to particular aspects of different disorders. A substantial proportion of the time during class will be allocated to discussing simulated therapy sessions and role-play on videotapes. The students are expected to do their own readings before coming to class.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students are expected to:

1. equip with a life-span developmental perspective in understanding the development of psychopathology, constituting a

basis for diagnostic consideration and intervention planning,

2. acquire basic competence to perform intake diagnostic interview, assessment, diagnostic formulation, case

conceptualization and treatment planning, as well as to practise psychological intervention in treating various childhood

and adolescent psychiatric disorders as illustration of the treatment processes.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Developmental psychopathology

2. Diagnostic interview, assessment, diagnostic formulation, case conceptualization, & treatment planning

3. Parent-training

4. Family therapy

5. Behavioural and cognitive therapies for children and adolescents

6. Matching treatments to disorders: Fine-tuning common treatment processes to particular aspects of different disorders

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Intervention Seminar III: Special Topics
courses.description: The course consists of two parts. The first part focuses on the clinical management of clients with a history of psychological trauma. The management of a client with trauma history is challenging. This difficulty comes from various aspects, including unstable therapeutic relationships, acute crises, and the intrusions of trauma memories. A series of topics are designed to cover these issues. The second part of the course is devoted to a process-oriented view of psychotherapy. Process-oriented treatment targets the general patterns and common factors of psychotherapy, especially the interpersonal transaction between a client and a therapist. Studying the process of psychotherapy is expected to increase the flexibility in clinical practice.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MSSc Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through practice, first-hand experience, sharing and reflections on specific intervention approaches that are commonly used by clinical psychologists, students would be able to :

1. learn new clinical skills in assessment, interpretation, and treatment,
2. plan and present intervention programs in selected topics in clinical psychology,
3. become more sensitive to the process of and the socio-cultural values in psychological intervention,
4. gain more confidence as a clinician.
courses.course_syllabus:
Psychological treatment for patients with a history of psychological trauma

- - Trauma spectrum disorders and childhood trauma

- - Phase-oriented therapy

- - Pathological trauma memory and memory reprocessing

- - Stabilization, grounding, and crisis management

- - The attachment framework and therapeutic alliance

The relational process of psychotherapy: Empathy

- - How many dialogues in a therapeutic room? One, two, or three?

- - From inter- to intra-personal affect regulation

- - The perspective of cognitive-behavioral therapy

- - The perspective of experientialism

- - The perspective of psychoanalysis and psychodynamics

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Neuroimaging Methods in Psychology
courses.description: This course introduces common neuroimaging methods in psychological research, e.g., EEG/ERP, MEG, structural and functional MRI, fNIRS and EROS. Specifically, biological basis of the brain signals measured, physical principles underlying the imaging methods, signal processing techniques, experimental design for neuroimaging studies, pre-processing procedures, statistical analyses, and interpretation of imaging data will be discussed. This course emphasizes both theoretical and practical aspects in the application of neuroimaging methods.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Psychology or MPhil-PhD Ind-Organizational Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, students will be able to:
1. explain concepts and procedures commonly encountered in neuroimaging
2. appreciate how neuroimaging improves our understanding of psychology
3. examine and evaluate primary neuroimaging research
4. gain hands-on experience in neuroimaging research

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Future Directions in Clinical Psychological Science
courses.description: This course explores emerging trends and innovations in clinical psychological science, with emphasis on interdisciplinary, multi-leveled ecological perspectives on evidence-based practices, service planning, and transformation. Students will examine cutting-edge research, including advancements in neuropsychology, novel approaches in mental health interventions, and culturally informed approaches. The course will also focus on the strategic development of psychological services in promotion, prevention, and treatment to address diverse community needs, ensuring accessibility and effectiveness. Through critical analysis and collaborative discussions, students will identify the implications of these developments for clinical practice and policy. By the end of the course, students will be equipped to contribute to the evolving landscape of clinical psychological science and address contemporary challenges in mental health care.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes:
| Students will be equipped with cutting-edge knowledge of emerging trends in clinical psychological science, such as those in the areas of psychopathology, neuropsychology, technology in mental health interventions, cultural diversity and multicultural competence, population-based approaches, and systems of care. Students will be able to demonstrate an ability to synthesize the body of knowledge and critically apply it to tackle pressing concerns and steer future directions in clinical psychology. |
| --- |
courses.course_syllabus: Specific topics and contents may evolve subject to the changing trends in clinical psychological science. Topic areas will include, but not limited to, developmental psychopathology, neuropsychology, novel psychological approaches, diversity and multicultural competence, service planning, development, and implementation.

courses.subject: PSYC
courses.title: Clinical Supervision: Theory and Practice
courses.description: This course systematically addresses the theory and practice of clinical supervision for professional psychologists, encompassing the knowledge, skills, attitudes, and ethical aspects. Students will examine up-to-date research evidence of clinical supervision as a core competency for professional psychologists, including theories and models that pertain to general frameworks as well as those specific for treatment modalities. Discussions and critical analyses will facilitate in-depth conceptualisation on issues such as ethical practice, reflective practice, diversity and inclusivity, giving and receiving feedback, and supervisory bond. Role-plays and skill practices will enable students to come up with realistic plans about how to set up clinical supervision and design supervisory activities strategically, provide evaluation constructively, and handle difficult situations effectively. As future leaders of the field, students will be encouraged to see beyond the dyad of an individual supervisor and the supervisee, but to gain insights into how to integrate good practices of clinical supervision into professional psychologists’ day-to-day services, promote sustainable professional development and improvement of clinical care, and cultivate a growth mindset in their work culture.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in PhD Clinical Psychology
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of this course, students will be able to: (i) demonstrate a deep understanding of the theoretical foundations and evidence-based practices of clinical supervision; (ii) implement strategies for providing constructive guidance for professional development and fostering supervisee growth; (iii) engage in reflective practice to continuously improve their supervisory skills, being aware of the intrapersonal, interpersonal, and contextual issues around their practices; and (iv) demonstrate a commitment to promoting the highest standards of professional practice and ethical conduct in clinical supervision.
courses.course_syllabus: Topic areas will include, but are not limited to, the following: Clinical supervision as a core competency for professional psychologists; roles and functions of clinical supervisors; developmental models of clinical psychologists and supervisors; attachment models of clinical supervision; modality-specific models of clinical supervision; ethical and legal issues in relation to clinical supervision; diversity and cultural sensitivity in supervisory practice; supervisory goals; supervisory tasks; supervisory bond; individual vs. group; reflective practice and questioning techniques; record keeping and governance; use of technology in supervision; feedback and evaluation; emotional support for the supervisee; self-care and resources for the supervisor; supervision of supervision; and creating a collaborative and supportive work environment conducive to good practices in clinical supervision.
courses.required_readings: To be decided by instructor as appropriate at the time of course offering
courses.recommended_readings:

* *Supervision competency scales:**

Milne, D., & Reiser, R.P. (2014). SAGE: A scale for rating competence in CBT supervision, in Watkins & Milne (Eds). International Handbook of Clinical Supervision. Wiley.

* *Modality-specific supervision:**

McNeill, B.W., & Stoltenberg, C.D. (2015). *Supervision Essentials for the Integrative Developmental Model.* APA.

Wade, J., & Jones, J. (2014). *Strength-Based Clinical Supervision: A Positive Psychology Approach to Clinical Training.* Springer.

* *Reflective and ethical practice:**

* *Supervisory goals, tasks, and bond:**

courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with the opportunity to delve deeply into the realm of clinical research, providing a comprehensive understanding of the principles, methodologies, and ethical considerations that underpin this field. Under the guidance and supervision of a faculty member, students have the freedom to investigate specifialised areas of interest within the landscape of clinical research that is tailored to their chosen area of focus, distinct from their primary thesis work. This personalised approach ensures that the topic and content of the study are individually crafted to maximise the learning experience for each student.
